story:
Please see our new campaign at: http://igg.me/at/pollinationgarden2/x/2411804

Thank you!

My name is Lauren, and I want to bring an educational beehive enclosure and pollination garden to my green neighborhood in Seattle, Washington.

Why?

High Point is home to many Somali, Cambodian, and Vietnamese families, and cultivating honey bees is part of our shared heritage.

Being part of the solution is a good thing. Bees are in trouble; we need them, and they need our help.

Pollination – West Seattle has beautiful plants and lush P-Patches– let’s keep them happy and pollinated

Honey to share and enjoy

Increased educational opportunities for kids and adults alike

 

Background

Honey bees pollinate 30% of all the food we eat and 80% of all fruits and vegetables. The global honey bee population has suffered a dramatic decline in recent years. Wild honey bee populations in the US have decreased by 50% over the past 50 years, and bee colonies maintained by beekeepers have decreased by about two thirds. This is due to a variety of reasons - most of them man-made. Without intervention, the continued demise of these incredible pollinators would have a dramatic effect on our ecosystems and food supply.

I had heard about the plight of the honey bee, but I wasn't fully aware of the situation and importance until I saw the film Vanishing of the Bees. I posted my idea on the West Seattle Blog asking how my neighbors felt about installing an educational beehive in a local P-Patch. The response was incredible and truly inspiring! So here we are, after more than a year, with a beautiful space for the bees and a pollination garden, a huge level of community support, local beekeepers to help us out (one has even taken me under her wing as an apprentice), pledged labor and funding from the High Point Neighborhood Association and Seattle P-Patch for sustained maintenance into the future, and a Department of Neighborhoods grant to get things rolling.

How you can help

We've come so far, but we need your support for the final push. We've gotten here thanks to the excitement and support of people just like you- friends who offered their time, money, expertise, and dedication. Will you join us? 

Every bit counts towards our goal. A donation of $5 buys one square foot of mulch for our garden- $250 fully outfits a novice beekeeper.  

So spread the word! Donate what you can, and tell friends and family. Best of all, come join us! Sign up to volunteer at an upcoming work party, and we'll see you in the garden.

**Updated since campaign created in February**

Good news: Due to continued donated materials, labor and money (outside of our indiegogo campaign), our goal is now $8,000! Wow, big change! We can't change the official goal for this campaign, but wanted to let you know that we aren't as far off as you may think!

What is the money for?

Thanks to the Seattle Department of Neighborhoods and other contributions, here is what we have:

- Fence for the pollination garden ($3,000 for material and labor)

- Polycarbonate to enable a transparent and secure beehive enclosure ($4,000)

- Remaining materials for the 9' tall beehive enclosure and shed ($3,000)

- Landscaping and grading, etc. ($2,000) - (this includes wood chips, gravel, compost, and plants for gardens, much of this is being donated as well)

- 2 traditional beehives and stands, butterfly house and mason bee structure ($500) - actual cost is $1250, but $750 worth is being donated)

- Equipment rental ($2,000)

- Materials to install a waterline, spigot and sink ($500)

-Translation and interpretation - final community meeting, invitations to meetings and work parties  ($1000)

- Supplies for mosaic (currently being constructed by WSE students) – ($200)

- Permit to build enclosure – ($520)

- Work party supplies, tools, tent ($1,000)

- Honeybees and mason bee larva ($300)

- Stainless steel donor’s sign ($300)

- Pavers ($100)

- Translation and interpretation (four languages) for signs and events so that everyone can participate ($1,500) 

-Solid wooden benches, enough for an entire classroom ($1,000). Acquired free lumbar from a local fallen tree, and help from a local furniture builder)

- Colorful educational signs ($4000) - (total funding goal for signs is $6500)

 

How your contributions will be spent:

- Colorful educational signs on the enclosure and throughout the park: $2500 (in order to reach $6500 goal for signs)

- Beekeeping equipment, enough to share ($1,500)

- Food and drinks for volunteers during work parties ($1,000)

- 2 additional beehives with frames from Shipwreck Honey -local hive carpenter ($1000)

- WiFi webcam to place at entrance of hive - would create interactive component for visitors, and research opportunities for local educators ($250)

- Small solar panel for basic power ($500)

- Live demonstration supplies ($500)

- Additional educational signs for demonstrations (would purchase with any additional funding left over)

 

 

 

The Impact

The West Seattle Bee and Pollination Garden will teach visitors, residents and school children about bees and pollination. The beehives will be enclosed inside a primarily transparent enclosure. This enclosure heightens the flight path of the bees, minimizing direct human interaction and protecting curious children from getting too close to the hives. The space will be surrounded by beautiful flowers and trees, illustrating the symbiotic relationship of bees and plants.

Schools will be welcome to take field trips to the hives and see demonstrations with the bees. Visitors will learn about bees and pollinators through posted signs and observing the hives. Our community, families and local groups will be welcome to host meetings in the space. Seattle residents and community members will learn new skills and share experiences by being part of this great project.

By hosting bees and educating residents, High Point continues its environmental stewardship. Everyone is invited to our first annual Bee Parade & Picnic on May 19, 2013 to welcome the bees to their new home, learn about bees, and enjoy our beautiful park.

This is due to a variety of reasons - most of them man-made. Without intervention, the continued demise of these incredible pollinators would have a dramatic effect on our ecosystems and food supply.
I had heard about the plight of the honey bee, but I wasn't fully aware of the situation and importance until I saw the film Vanishing of the Bees. I posted my idea on the West Seattle Blog asking how my neighbors felt about installing an educational beehive in a local P-Patch. The response was incredible and truly inspiring! So here we are, after more than a year, with a beautiful space for the bees and a pollination garden, a huge level of community support, local beekeepers to help us out (one has even taken me under her wing as an apprentice), pledged labor and funding from the High Point Neighborhood Association and Seattle P-Patch for sustained maintenance into the future, and a Department of Neighborhoods grant to get things rolling.
How you can help
We've come so far, but we need your support for the final push. We've gotten here thanks to the excitement and support of people just like you- friends who offered their time, money, expertise, and dedication. Will you join us? 
Every bit counts towards our goal. A donation of $5 buys one square foot of mulch for our garden- $250 fully outfits a novice beekeeper.  
So spread the word! Donate what you can, and tell friends and family. Best of all, come join us! Sign up to volunteer at an upcoming work party, and we'll see you in the garden.

**Updated since campaign created in February**
Good news: Due to continued donated materials, labor and money (outside of our indiegogo campaign), our goal is now $8,000! Wow, big change! We can't change the official goal for this campaign, but wanted to let you know that we aren't as far off as you may think!
What is the money for?
Thanks to the Seattle Department of Neighborhoods and other contributions, here is what we have:
- Fence for the pollination garden ($3,000 for material and labor)
- Polycarbonate to enable a transparent and secure beehive enclosure ($4,000)
- Remaining materials for the 9' tall beehive enclosure and shed ($3,000)
- Landscaping and grading, etc. ($2,000) - (this includes wood chips, gravel, compost, and plants for gardens, much of this is being donated as well)
- 2 traditional beehives and stands, butterfly house and mason bee structure ($500) - actual cost is $1250, but $750 worth is being donated)
- Equipment rental ($2,000)
- Materials to install a waterline, spigot and sink ($500)
-Translation and interpretation - final community meeting, invitations to meetings and work parties  ($1000)
- Supplies for mosaic (currently being constructed by WSE students) – ($200)
- Permit to build enclosure – ($520)
- Work party supplies, tools, tent ($1,000)
- Honeybees and mason bee larva ($300)
- Stainless steel donor’s sign ($300)
- Pavers ($100)
- Translation and interpretation (four languages) for signs and events so that everyone can participate ($1,500) 
-Solid wooden benches, enough for an entire classroom ($1,000). Acquired free lumbar from a local fallen tree, and help from a local furniture builder)
- Colorful educational signs ($4000) - (total funding goal for signs is $6500)
 
How your contributions will be spent:
- Colorful educational signs on the enclosure and throughout the park: $2500 (in order to reach $6500 goal for signs)
- Beekeeping equipment, enough to share ($1,500)
- Food and drinks for volunteers during work parties ($1,000)
- 2 additional beehives with frames from Shipwreck Honey -local hive carpenter ($1000)
- WiFi webcam to place at entrance of hive - would create interactive component for visitors, and research opportunities for local educators ($250)
- Small solar panel for basic power ($500)
- Live demonstration supplies ($500)
- Additional educational signs for demonstrations (would purchase with any additional funding left over)
 
 
 
The Impact
The West Seattle Bee and Pollination Garden will teach visitors, residents and school children about bees and pollination. The beehives will be enclosed inside a primarily transparent enclosure. This enclosure heightens the flight path of the bees, minimizing direct human interaction and protecting curious children from getting too close to the hives. The space will be surrounded by beautiful flowers and trees, illustrating the symbiotic relationship of bees and plants.
Schools will be welcome to take field trips to the hives and see demonstrations with the bees. Visitors will learn about bees and pollinators through posted signs and observing the hives. Our community, families and local groups will be welcome to host meetings in the space. Seattle residents and community members will learn new skills and share experiences by being part of this great project.

By hosting bees and educating residents, High Point continues its environmental stewardship. Everyone is invited to our first annual Bee Parade & Picnic on May 19, 2013 to welcome the bees to their new home, learn about bees, and enjoy our beautiful park.

story:
WHAT WE'RE ABOUT!

Can a Salon mean more than a haircut? 

Our vision of education, charity fundraising, and community building, will propel Strut toward industry leadership, while nurturing a welcoming home for our gifted staff, fabulous clients, and our Portland community!  So... Is it possible?

 

HOW CAN YOU HELP?!

The list of to-dos is long, and the funds being raised are for absolute essentials:

Space: The remainder of Strut Salon’s lease!

Painting: Supplies to give the walls, floor, and ceiling a facelift!

Lighting: New fixtures, so we’ll see your beautiful hair shine!

Retail: A dedicated area to host everything our clients could need!

Website: A friendly destination to keep you up, scheduled, and in touch!

P.O.S.: A booking/managing/sales system!

Alarm: Installing Strut’s alarm system to keep us safe!

Any amount raised within my goal goes straight to these items, and any additional funds will go toward the second list:

Color Processors (2)!     

New Mats!                            

New Carts!                     

New Shampoo Bowls(3)!      

Brand New Chairs!                      

We have big plans here at Strut, and a bright future ahead of us!  It all starts here!

 

WHAT YOU GET!

Our perks are so exciting: from a care package of hair supplies tucked in a coffee mug, client and stylist workshops, to a year of hair services! 

You can have your mug with a "My Hairchick" logo, or a "Strut Salon" logo.  Whichever makes you smile more while sipping your hot beverage!

 

I cut any hair: international hair, kids' hair, mom's and dad's hair.  My job is to make you and yours look as perfect as possible!

 

 

Once the Salon is finished in mid-late July, we'll hold a Grand Reopening, with tours, drinks, and entertainment!  Get a VIP pass to the event, where I comp your drinks and give you the stars' treatment!  It's the least I can do!

 

 

Have a look and see what we can do in return for your amazing support, right over there —>

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP!

Please spread the word!  Whether you’re a client and part of the Strut family, a caring member of our community, or you just want to see us succeed!  If our jobs, goals, and motivations speak to you:

“Like” Strut Salon on Facebook!

#StrutSalonPDX

Send me a message through IndieGoGo or my website to keep me going!

Spread this video and campaign to everyone else who, like you, wants to see Strut reach its full potential!

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Short Summary

Inspiration and Motivation

My name is Bashir Munye and I am the Chef/Founder of My Little Dumplings. You may have seen me in Food and Drink Magazine, or at farmer's markets around Toronto, offering up global, seasonal, farm-fresh dumplings and steam buns. The inspiration for My Little Dumplings comes from my wife, Asha, and our own three "little dumplings," Hamza, Zenzi and Lula. My passion for food is more than a desire to cook great things. I believe that everyone should have access to healthy, wholesome food. Our new kitchen will be a space where we can create new, innovative items and expand our commitment to making organic, farm-to-table food accessible to a wider community.
My Little Dumplings... our very first day at the market.

From a culinary perspective, I'm a bit of a nomad

I was born in Somalia, grew up in Italy, and for the last 20 years, have made Toronto my home. My love of globally-inspired foods comes honestly. My mother was a great cook who prepared Somalian, Ethiopian, Italian and Kenyan fare... foods like roasted camel, goat meat, and injera - an Ethiopian staple. Throughout my childhood, fresh, seasonal organic food was the norm. As we traveled across the Mediterranean, I remember visiting presses where Italian families would bring olives from their trees to make their own oil. In France, Spain, and Switzerland, I grew to appreciate pâté and croissants, and later in Tunisia, couscous, Merguez, and Harissa. As an African in the diaspora, my inspirations are drawn from
all these diverse influences, and folded into little morsels of goodness.
      
We need a permanent, commercial space
For the past three years, we have been cooking in shared commercial rental kitchens and selling primarily at farmer's markets. Demand for our products and catering has increased to the point where we can no longer meet our customers' needs. We want to secure a permanent commercial kitchen so that we can:
  • Scale up production for artisanal global organic dumplings
  • Increase our capacity to cater customized events
  • Develop home replacement meals
  • Prepare, process, and package our original sauces and condiments
  • Increase our presence at farmer's markets across the GTA
  • Increase our support for food literacy programs
  • Provide training and mentorship for youth and new immigrants 
  • Continue to support local farmers & the artisanal business community 


Our goal is to raise $45,000

This will enable us to lease a commercial space in Toronto and purchase the required equipment, including:

  • Industrial bake and steam oven - $16,000
  • Large dough sheeter - $2,800
  • Large dough mixer - $3,200
  • Walk-in fridge and freezer - $12,000
  • Vacuum Packaging Machine - $3,000
  • 6 burner gas stove - $2,000
  • Electrical & Plumbing - $3,500
  • Shelving, racks, tables, etc. - $2,500                                                                                           

What happens if we do not reach our goal?

If we do not reach our goal (we are really hoping that we do), then we will use the funds to secure the new space and prioritize our needs. We would have to reduce the scale of the operation and continue to build slowly. For example, we would still secure the space and some equipment depending on how much we raise. Making artisanal dumplings (everything from scratch) is very labour intensive. At the moment, every step of the process is done by hand and from farm to table.This takes lots of time. While we are proud of this fact, scaling up will allow us to become more efficient without compromising quality. We would then be able to focus on growing other aspects of the business and the community programs we wish to support and create.

You'll get a delicious return for your contribuition

Depending on your contribution level, you will get:

  • Dumpling Dollars -- redeemable for our delicious dumplings
  • My Little Dumplings recipes -- our customers' favourites
  • Handwritten thank-you note from Chef Bashir
  • Invitation to a post-campaign Celebration Cocktail Party
  • A farm-fresh, seasonal and organic menu for up to 10 people, catered by Chef Bashir in the comfort of your home.

It's a tasty proposition...

These dumplings are unique on the Toronto food scene. From Kobucha squash or duck confit dumplings to Bajan Beef Cheek Bao (steam bun), the fillings tap into traditions from around the world... a representation of Toronto.

We have the talent, the recipes, the principals, the work ethic, and a dedicated foodie following from the markets. We need your support to continue to grow!

Please join us on this culinary adventure.

You can help other ways too

  • Please spread the word about our campaign to your friends.
  • Looking for a holiday gift? Consider donating on behalf of family or friends.

story:
Short Summary

Third Perk Coffeehouse & Wine Bar opened its doors on June 16 of this year.  We have become a Dayton favorite.  We are proud of the success that we have experienced thus far.  I am Juanita-Michelle, the owner and manager of Third Perk.  I have invested my heart, soul, energy and every dollar into opening Third Perk.  But it is such an amazing reward.  Third Perk is doing exactly what I planned it to do, it is a community meeting place where all are welcomed to spend time.  Third Perk is a great picture of what our community really looks like.  

I find students, professionals, retirees, and other business owners meeting at Third Perk.  I find individuals and group spending time just enjoying the great products and the atmosphere that Third Perk offers.  Now we get an opportunity to expand our service to the library.  AMAZING!

What We Need & What You Get

We need capital to get this project off the ground.  We need the help of our community!

  • Third Perk is a self-funded business, we have exhausted our resources and could use the help of the community to help raise $7,000.  
  • We are offering some cool items for participating.  
  • We are using the contributions to help purchase equipment for the new location.  If we reach our entire goal your funds will help us purchase a shiny new espresso machine.
  • If we do not meet our entire goal, we will use the funds donated to help purchase the machine.
  • If we exceed our goal we will be able to purchase more items needed for the entire project.

The Impact

Third Perk is vested in the Dayton community.  Since our opening only six months ago Third Perk has proven that it will pour into the community and share its resources to help make our City better.  Here are some of the things that we have worked on as a company:

  • Tipping for Teachers!  In August we distributed over $600 in school supplies to teachers of Dayton Public Schools.  As a company we want to contribute to teachers so that they have the tools needed to help their students succeed.
  • Billi's Believers.  Third Perk helped a local resident raise monies towards her charity, 
  • Third Perk has made donations and contributed to many other organizatons in the Dayton area including: Mercy Manor, Air Force Institute of Technology Spouses Association, American Cancer Society, $ Paws for Ability, and 
  • Perk-U-Lator Entrepreneur Contest.  We will award an upcoming entrepreneur $1,000 to use as capital to launch their new business venture.  As a new entrepreneur I understand the struggle and challenges of securing capital to start a business.  I believe that my City needs more small businesses so I want to be an instrument in assisting their visions become a reality. 
With the expansion of the Third Perk brand we will continue to work hard to insure that we do our part in making the Dayton area a better community.

Risks & Challenges

Third Perk is already an established business.  Although we have created a good reputation in the Dayton area we have miles to go before we are able to say that we are a Dayton landmark.  Without the help of creative funding such as Indiegogo Third Perk this project will be in jeopardy of getting off the ground.  

Your contribution will assist our company in opening with the 

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to make a financial contribution to our campaign, we would still appreciate your support.  Here are a few things you could do: 

  • Tell others about Third Perk Coffeehouse & Wine Bar downtown Dayton and ask them to visit.
  • Tell others about our campaign.  Guide them to this site and ask them to help us out.  $1 will make a big difference.
  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and Instragram.  
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hello there! My name is Nicole Tetherow and I am currently a student athlete at California Lutheran University. I'm majoring in Marketing Communication and am a captain of the Division III Women's Volleyball Team at California Lutheran University. 

I am currently enrolled in an Event Planning class and a Funding for Non-profits class this semester. While learning the high cost and stress involved with fundraisers, I have been challenged to campaign and raise money for a foundation of my choice. I decided to raise money for the wonderful foundation called ‘Life Rolls On’.  For those of you who don't know, Life Rolls On (LRO) is a 501(c)(3) non profit dedicated to improving the quality of life for young people affected by spinal cord injuries. This foundation puts on events in local areas, such as Santa Monica or Venice, that allows kids and young adults to participate in activities that they once thought were impossible.

I came across this foundation when I volunteered at the U.S. Surf Open last summer, where I was fortunate to meet Jesse Billauer, the founder and CEO of LRO, as well as the 2015 World Champion of Quadriplegic Surfing. His positive attitude and drive to live life to the fullest, beyond paralysis, really motivated me to get involved with nonprofits; specifically this one!

As a college student, I know best how tight money can be. All I ask is if you could give up that coffee you usually get and donate that $5 to this campaign. Because that $5 is going to go towards helping and turning some young kids idea of her/his "impossible" into possible. Which to me, is worth way more than any amount of money.

I plan to raise at least $500 to help support LRO in their event 'They Will Surf Again' that will take place on June 4th in Santa Monica this summer. All donations go towards extra necessities such as food, drinks, giveaways, etc to help make it a great experience for those young children and families.

Now that you've gotten to learn about me and my reasons for starting this campaign, please click 'Contribute Now'! Also, do not be afraid to share my campaign with friends or family because even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! :) 

To learn more about LRO, check out their website at www.liferollson.org

Thank you and God bless!

story:
Shannon Marie Rico (nee Broza) was surrounded by her family when at the young age of 42 her hard fought struggle with cancer ended.  Shannon passed away on Saturday October 3, 2015.  She will be dearly missed by her husband, Jonathan and her children Brenden, Joshua, Hayley and Nicolas.

Shannon is remembered for her love and devotion to her children, her outgoing personality, her love for life, her inner strength and her immeasurable kindness.  She is missed by everyone who had the privilege of knowing her.

This fund has been created by friends with the blessing of the family.  Any funds raised will be deposited in Trust for Shannon's four children to be divided equally among them and used to honour her memory in the months and years that come. 

Many family and friends came together to remember Shannon and share love with her children, Jonathan and extended family.  However, the healing and recovery period will continue on when many of us have gotten back to the dailyness of living our busy lives.  

Shannon will never be far from our thoughts but when we are back to our normal, her children will still be without their mother.  The significant emotional and financial toll will be felt for a long time.  

Our hope for the money raised is to be used for a family vacation at a particularly difficult time of year (Christmas, or now Thanksgiving), to ease the burden of post secondary education, or any other way that will remind them of their Mother's Love and the Love of those who also Loved her.

We approached Jon about creating this page when we wished we could do more for the kids.  There is a small sense of helping when we hoped we could somehow create a fund that could help bring those beautiful smiles back in the future.  

Michelle Phillips and Allan Paterson

story:
We are a group of artists, activists, musicians, students, and rabble-rousers who formed an anarchist collective in late 2013 for promoting community action in Phoenix. Many of our ideas and projects have run into the never-ending conflicts of finding space, money and time to carry as far as we would like. We started searching for a home base, a space we could use to launch bigger, more sustainable projects for genuine community growth and involvement; a space that will grow organically to fit the needs and goals of the people. We wanted a music venue, theater, infoshop, anarchist library, community garden, meeting space, a resource center, a food bank… Spaces are already being built and maintained by peers in Flagstaff and Tucson, but we don’t have a permanent anarchist venue in the Phoenix area. The space we envision will be maintained by the collective, but its projects will come from anyone who has an idea and the drive to see it through.

We have already found a perfect location, a working class neighborhood in Tempe, Arizona. The building is available for our collective to purchase and the owner is willing to work with us on making that happen, but we need to raise funds. Before we can open the doors, we will need to put in more work to build a stage, put in bookshelves, set up a community kitchen, and other projects. We have volunteers to help with renovation and create the garden as well as paint the place. We're all set and ready to go; we just need to pay the deposit to get the keys! We believe in this project so much, most of us have given everything we can and more to making it happen. We need help with the initial down payment for the building, and we decided as a group to ask the people for help. 

We respect that many other groups in the Valley are building their own projects around local issues. To help support those efforts with our fundraising push, we have been able to offer rewards for contributions of $20 or more.  These will range from personalized shirts, custom stickers, professional banners and discounts on events and free shows.

What we earn will go towards the down payment, renovations and resources, regardless of whether we reach our goal or not. Anything you can contribute will alleviate the financial pressure of the individuals who have been putting everything on the line to see this space open its doors. If we hit our $5,000 goal, great! If we go over, even better! And if we don't reach it, we will still continue to fight for an open resource center to serve the community and all funds will be dedicated to that purpose.

This space will be invaluable to the Phoenix community. It will provide a safe space for people who feel marginalized and foster resistance to systemic oppression. It will strengthen ties within our community and provide tools and space to strategize for a life that we love. It will be a venue for local artists and bands, a practice space, a meeting space, a library, a kitchen, a garden and a shelter from the storm. The space will be alive, with zines, screenprinting, music, art, skill sharing and a communal garden for everyone. This is the biggest and most ambitious project that we have started, but it is only the beginning. Help us build.

Please share our fundraising page, and keep in touch! We will have lots of opportunities to become involved in building this space. We can't wait to work with you.

story:
Short Summary

Providence Recovery Center's mission is to provide faith based teaching along with evidence based methodologies to more effectively serve our clients  and our community.

Jon and Stacy Dorsey serve to bring healing and recovery to those struggling with addiction, hurts and paralyzing, emotional pain.

Dave Avina, with God's help is able to counsel, teach and develop a custom fit treatment program embracing the holistic wellness approach

What We Need & What You Get


  • $8,000 security deposit
  • $1,150 to set up needed home care items such as lawnmower, garden hose, tools, trash cans, ladder, etc.
  • $500 for paint and cleaning product
  • $500 for Utility establishment and deposits
  • $350 for moving truck rental

The Impact

Nationwide, women are under-represented in addiction treatment. While about 30% of all people with addiction problems are women, they make up only 20-25 percent of those in treatment. Women tend to come into treatment much later in their addiction than men, often showing prolonged, deteriorating conditions. They frequently enter treatment as the result of a crisis, such as a break down in their health, a spousal beating, the threat of losing their children, or an arrest.  Other barriers are greater social shame, lack of money or health insurance, inadequate transportation, and lack of treatment services sensitive to gender needs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate wood furniture for the business management training, help paint, volunteer at the center, promote on your social websites, help move, bring us your recyclables:-)

story:
Please help us bring Jose back home. Jose was arrested on July 6th and is still in jail due to a hold from INS. Jose arrived in the US when he was twelve. He is now 25. He is an amazing art student. He graduated from high school and immediately went to community college. He earned his AA in Art, he then transferred to Cal State Fullerton where he is ready to begin his last year to earn his BA in Art. Jose is planning on applying for graduate school in the fall to eventually become a teacher.

 

While, Jose is not a legal citizen he is one of the people we wish we had more of in our country. He got a job at 17 washing dishes and 7 years later had moved his way up to being a server. He is well liked by his co-workers and his customers alike. Jose works hard to support his family. He has mostly raised his three little brothers while working and going to school full time. His mother is a single mother left with raising her three younger sons alone where she has always had the financial support and responsible adult to raise the boys.

 

His legal fees are mounting due to the fact we need to hire a criminal lawyer and an immigration attorney. Jose is being charged with unauthorized use of personal identifying information.  He also will fully qualify under the new Dream Act. He has been here since he was twelve, graduated high school here in the US, and is currently a full time student. We need Jose back to begin his final year of undergraduate work starting August 27th.

 

Jose is an amazing person to family, friends and the community. It would be a shame to not have him in our country.

story:
Summary (I'm putting it all out there)

As many of you know, I was divorced in 2009 and a month later I lost my job. For 2 solid years, I battled with (and have mostly won the war) on major full blown depression. I struggled to find anything that would help me support myself and my little miss. I was willing to take any job and applied to everything under the sun. I've had to carve my own plan to work - I have created businesses and I work as an independent contractor for companies I believe in and love. I work very hard and I'm proud of myself for getting out of the depression and out of the victim mode and really using my talents and resources. I have struggled so much to make ends meet and I've come so far in getting our lives on track. Now, I need a little help to get us to where we need to go next.

Last year, I was able to leave the apartment with the raining holes in the roof, bad memories, rusty pipes and 17 year old rug and moved into my sister's house. She generously offered for me to pay a small portion to live here. I have partially rented this house and we have found peace and tranquility that could not be found in that old place, under the flight path. I have found happiness despite barely surviving financially. Money has been a stressor but it was livable. I feel like my little miss and I both have been moving in the right direction.

Sometimes, things change so quickly. I have been so focused on life and building our future but thought I'd be able to stay in this house much longer. We have lived hand to mouth. Whatever else I've managed to earn, I've put toward growing Dulce Sweet, growing our future.  I found out on Monday that we need to move. My sister is now in a position where she immediately needs to rent it out entirely to cover the cost of the mortgage. And that makes sense and I understand it but I am not in a position to afford to pay that. 

When we moved last year, I got rid of all my furniture and everything we owned. My credit is shot. To make things easier for my ex (and thereby easier for me and my kid), I took the bulk of the debt at the time of the divorce, then lost my job, and have been dealing with that ever since. I thought we'd be here for a while and would have a chance to rebuild before we moved on. 

Yesterday, we went looking at places and theres so many immediate expenses involved in this. The added deposit because of the credit issue is enough to put me in this position. I'm asking for help in all of this. I'm asking because I'm at the end of my rope. I'm asking, openly and honestly, for a hand up. Help me and my little miss get a place of our own, help me get her a bed and a dresser and a place to hang her starkid's posters. Please.

story:
I currently have a bicycle and set of legs. I want to save for a scooter, motorcycle or car, your financial help would be greatly appreciated my fellow humans!

Only once before has a flood of any note occured in Duluth (1972), the recent flooding is of unprecedented power, a scourge on our material possessions...

thanks for considering!  

 

~(:^)}

story:
Who are we?

Welcome To My Yard is an innovative not-for-profit social enterprise working with Nepali young people on the street to provide holistic community based support, education, training, and income generation programmes. We hope that through our dedication and creative approaches to involve and inspire and enable young people we will have a positive social impact in the community.

 

The street children and young people of Kathmandu Nepal

The street community is made up of children and young people that are either street-living,street-families or may have basic accommodation but are forced onto the streets to provide for themselves (street-working). They age from 2-25 both girls and boys. No one knows the exact number of street children in Kathmandu Valley but estimates state over 1,000 with 500 new children and young people added to the streets every year. The reasons for street children are multiple and complex but include experiencing abuse and violence at home, witness to alcohol misuse, difficulties with step-parents or extreme poverty in rural areas forcing children to come to the city to seek work and then falling into a dangerous street life. Whilst on the streets they are at high risk of inhumane treatment, constant abuse and all types of exploitation from their peers, adults, employers and people in authority. Up to 75% of street boys are subject to continued sexual abuse and exploitation by other youths, adults and foreigners. Glue sniffing is relatively new in Nepal but is increasing at an alarming rate amongst this street community becoming a peer group activity. Street children as young as 5 are known to be sniffing dendrite which is a legal substance used as a carpet and shoe glue and its availability is difficult to control. The effects are instant: suppressing hunger and giving an anaesthetic effect. Deep breathing of the Dendrite or using a lot over a short period of time may result in losing touch with their surroundings, violent behaviour and loss of self -control unconsciousness or even death. In short, these incredibly vulnerable children and young people need support...

 

But thatâ€™s not all we know about this community.....

All the facts above are a terrifying reality for the street community that we work with, but we also know that out of the most difficult situations come many strengths and a great deal of resilience. Someoneâ€™s trauma is not the sum of who they are. These children, young people and young families also have many incredible resources, talents and abilities individually and as a community....in other words, they are amazing!!!! We want to partner with the children and young people to build on these strengths. This means partnering with them to help realise their potential , achieve their goals in life, through emotional support and equipping them with the tools they need to positively support themselves and their family.

 

What do we need?

We need a project centre in the heart of this street community. This will become a safe contact point in which children and young people can come, receive support and get into our programme which helps them with work experience, vocational training and education opportunities. The project space will run the innovative bite size education and education workshops, kids clubs and young peopleâ€™s groups and provide a place for our key workers to provide individual emotional support.

 

The Art Space

As part of our strengths based work, we want to dedicate an entire wall of our building just for them. Children & Young people will have the opportunity to use this space to express themselves in any way they like; murals, photographs, paintings and more! We will then exhibit their work for 2-3 months and invite the local community to come and see what they have created. Then, we will white wash and start all over again!

 

What will your donation cover?

Your funds will pay for the rent of a project space and bills for one year and purchase art materials. If we manage to raise over the amount, we will put it towards other much needed items for the project such as equipment and basic salaries for the team as currently we are all working as volunteers. 

 

Want to find our more?

You can see what we have been up to with the young people so far like our indoor rock climbing programme, street children photography book and see how we have funded young people already into education or vocational training.

Check out our website www.welcometomyyard.com, go to our Facebook Page â€˜Welcome to My Yardâ€™ or drop us an email at contact@welcometomyyard.com and we would be happy to answer any questions you have about what we are doing.

story:
In about 1.5 months, I'll be heading to India to spend my summer internship working with one of Kiva's local MFI partners WSDS, where I'll be supporting their efforts to help develop the businesses of small scale entrepreneurs and strengthen the Kiva partnership. I could NOT be more excited as it is one of Kiva's first partnerships in India !!!

My Story

Having worked in the private sector for five years in India, I wanted to do some impact driven work and be part of a more entrepreneurial environment in India by creating aggressive small scale investment programs. I felt the need to do MBA focusing on Social enterprise /International Development and traveled all the way to Washington, DC to study at Georgetown University.Looking for an opportunity that would provide me the necessary transformational experience for my summer internship, I chose to be a Kiva fellow. I knew Kiva would be a good start as Kiva does just that - creating small scale investment programs and connecting people with resources to entrepreneurs in need of resources.

The Kiva Fellows Program

The Kiva Fellow is an unpaid position designed to increase Kiva's impact and to offer participants like me a unique insider experience in the world of microfinance. The Kiva Fellow is an integral part of the Kiva Team, acting as Kiva's eyes and ears in the field and helping to extend limited resources to maximum effect. The Fellows focus on helping to improve the knowledge, capacity, and systems within their assigned Microfinance Institution (MFI).

You can read more about the Kiva Fellows program here:
http://www.kiva.org/about/fellows-program/

Why should you support

As the Kiva Fellows Program is an unpaid position I need your help in covering my expenses. In order to get there, live there, work there and learn all that this experience has to offer, I estimate it to cost me $5000.I am asking you to help me cover half of these through how much ever small donation you can make. This is a great opportunity for you to contribute to many worthy causes in a very impactful way and help me make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share my campaign

Want to help me reach out to people, Amazing!!! I would be grateful if you can share my campaign with your friends, family, colleagues, community groups, or anyone else who you think might support a great cause!

Want to just wish me good luck, AMAZING!!!

Thank You all for your support. I really appreciate it.

My Story
Having worked in the private sector for five years in India, I wanted to do some impact driven work and be part of a more entrepreneurial environment in India by creating aggressive small scale investment programs. I felt the need to do MBA focusing on Social enterprise /International Development and traveled all the way to Washington, DC to study at Georgetown University.Looking for an opportunity that would provide me the necessary transformational experience for my summer internship, I chose to be a Kiva fellow. I knew Kiva would be a good start as Kiva does just that - creating small scale investment programs and connecting people with resources to entrepreneurs in need of resources.
The Kiva Fellows Program
The Kiva Fellow is an unpaid position designed to increase Kiva's impact and to offer participants like me a unique insider experience in the world of microfinance. The Kiva Fellow is an integral part of the Kiva Team, acting as Kiva's eyes and ears in the field and helping to extend limited resources to maximum effect. The Fellows focus on helping to improve the knowledge, capacity, and systems within their assigned Microfinance Institution (MFI).
You can read more about the Kiva Fellows program here:http://www.kiva.org/about/fellows-program/
Why should you support
As the Kiva Fellows Program is an unpaid position I need your help in covering my expenses. In order to get there, live there, work there and learn all that this experience has to offer, I estimate it to cost me $5000.I am asking you to help me cover half of these through how much ever small donation you can make. This is a great opportunity for you to contribute to many worthy causes in a very impactful way and help me make a difference.
Other Ways You Can Help
Share my campaign
Want to help me reach out to people, Amazing!!! I would be grateful if you can share my campaign with your friends, family, colleagues, community groups, or anyone else who you think might support a great cause!
Want to just wish me good luck, AMAZING!!!
Thank You all for your support. I really appreciate it.

story:
Our Story

Andrew needs money to get to Guam at the beginning of 2011, and is diseased and cannot get that amount without your help!


The Impact

Andrew gets to have a place to live. He's struggling medically and cannot really afford it, but a friend is giving him a roof in Guam. 


What We Need 

Any sort of cash contribution will help greatly!

story:
This fundraiser is to help assist Mike's family with any bills or anything to help them out in this time of need. Mike had always done a good job at putting a smile on someone's face, so let's help put a smile on theirs in this time of grief. 

We are accepting anything we can get for donations, everything donated will be given to his family to help them with anything they need.

story:
Breve reseña

El movimiento Maker, la cultura de crear tecnología por tus propios medios, DIY (Do-It-Yourself), es un fenómeno social a nivel global al que Europa y España se están sumando. La comunidad de la que se nutre este movimiento son personas inquietas, apasionadas por la tecnología, educadores, artistas, informáticos, artesanos, ingenieros, estudiantes, defensores del código abierto y el trabajo colaborativo. En definitiva, todos aquellos cuyo pensamiento gira en torno a cómo inventar o crear cosas nuevas. Ahora, por primera vez en Valencia, podremos reunirnos todos durante los días 5, 6 y 7 de Junio en la Universidad Politécnica de Valencia para compartir nuestras experiencias y creaciones en la Mini Maker Faire Valencia 2014!

A lo largo de estos días tendremos la oportunidad de disfrutar de actividadesparalelas impartidas o presentadas por empresas, makers y especialistas en proyectos y tecnologías DIY. Se habilitarán espacios de encuentro, stands para que tanto makers como entidades participantes puedan exponer al público sus ideas, productos o servicios, así como cursos de formación, workshops y presentaciones rápidas sobre las últimas tecnologías actualmente en desarrollo.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Tu ayuda en la Maker Faire irá íntegramente destinada a sufragar los costes de la organización del evento, entre ellos: alquiler de stands, difusión del evento, conferencias, cartelería, etc.

A cambio, recibiréis las siguientes recompensas: 

A) Reconocimiento web ( 1€ o + ) ¡Gracias por tu apoyo! Te incluiremos en el apartado de "Impulsores" de la web de la Feria Maker

B) Sticker ( 5€ o + ) ¡Gracias por apoyarnos! Te incluiremos en la web además de darte un sticker (pegatina) de la Feria Maker

C) Chapa Maker ( 10€ o + ) Aparecerás en la web, y además tendrás una chapa de la Feria Maker

D) LLavero Maker ( 15€ o + ) Recibirás un llavero con tu apoyo, y el reconocimiento en la web de la Feria Maker

E) Camiseta Maker Te incluiremos en la web como impulsor, y además una EXCLUSIVA camiseta Maker

F) Kit Feria Maker ( 50€ o + ) ¡El kit Maker Faire! Reconocimiento en la web + sticker + chapa + llavero + camiseta. ¿Quién da más?

G) Busto 3D ( 75€ o + ) ¿Quieres una copia de tí mismo en 3D? Te escanearemos e imprimiremos en 3D una copia de tu busto

H) Bono FabLab ( 100€ o + ) Incluye 5 horas gratis en el FabLab Valencia donde podrás cortar, mecanizar, o imprimir en 3D tu diseño.

I) KIT NIÑOS (7-15 años): Summer Camp de Robótica en Droide (150€)

+A elegir entre 23-27 junio de 10 a 13h o 30 junio-4 julio de 10 a 13h. 

+Talleres con Lego Mindstorms. Reto Ciudad Ecológica.

+Para más información: Droide Comunidad

J) UNA PLAZA para el BOOTCAMP 23-27 Junio 2014 (UPV) en FabLab VLC (160€)

+Curso de introducción a las tecnologicas de fabricación.

K) Curso de Introducción a Arduino en Hackerspace Valencia (169€)

+10 horas con Starter Kit de Arduino includo. 

Si eres una entidad o empresa, puedes encontrar información detallada sobrepatrocinios aquí:

http://issuu.com/magisgi3/docs/dossier_patrocinio_mfvlc#

¿Quiénes somos?

Los organizadores del evento somos un equipo de personas formado por:

Impulsanto la iniciativa y aportando los recursos disponibles, 

Fablab Valencia, Makers UPV, Droide Comunidad,Hackerspace Valencia, Lion Click.

Ante cualquier duda, contacta con nosotros a la siguiente dirección:

makerfairevalencia@gmail.com


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Quizás no puedas colaborar económicamente, pero eso no significa que no puedas ayudar:

  • Difunde la campaña y genera eco puedes usar las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.
  • ¿Conoces a algún posible patrocinador? ¡Perfecto! Ponte en contacto con nosotros y buscaremos la forma que participe.
  • ¿Eres Maker? ¿Conoces a alguien que sí lo es? Invítalo a que participe en la feria y muestre lo que sabe hacer.

story:
We Want To Help You Snack Fearlessly!

Everyone should be able to choose a health-conscious, gluten free and allergen free candy - that actually tastes amazing - from their local store.  Many companies have tried, but there are still very few healthy, tasty options beyond the Twix and Reese's of the world.  Sun Cups wants to change that.

To succeed as a small business against these big competitors we need your help to raise awareness of Sun Cups.  We need more people to know about us, hear our story, and try our delicious, nut- and gluten-free chocolate products.  The more people who support us, the better chance we have to grow from being a small business startup, to providing the public with mainstream, health-conscious, safe-for-everyone candy options.  And the sooner we grow, the sooner we’ll have the funds to go dairy-free, a recipe we’ve developed and are ready to roll out in production.

Raising awareness costs money, money we simply don’t have.  That’s why we are reaching out to our loyal community to ask you to support our Indiegogo campaign.  With help, we can continue to produce high quality, delicious, non-GMO, gluten-free, nut allergen-free, rainforest-certified, soon to be dairy-free chocolate products.        

So what will we do with the money we raise?

We want to be able to send samples to every single food allergy walk in the country.  This way, nut- and peanut-allergic children will have the chance to taste and enjoy, some for the very first time, a delicious chocolate cup that they can find locally in Whole Foods and with your help, regular grocery stores!

100% of the funds you donate will be used to produce Sun Cups and distribute them to the various food allergy walks around the country.  Every dollar donated means another child with food allergies will get to enjoy a tasty Sun Cup! Now is the time for a mainstream candy product that will meet the needs of people who eat peanut-free, nut free, tree nut free and gluten-free.  

We need your help!  Support us by donating to this campaign and joining the #SunCupArmy.



Our Story

Sun Cups were born out of a parent’s simple desire to have their allergic child experience the joy of a peanut butter cup.

Four years ago, Seth Ellis Chocolatier, the maker of some of the world’s most decadent chocolate indulgences, was approached by a family whose son was deathly allergic to peanuts.

The father handed founder David Lurie a jar of homemade roasted sunflower seed butter and asked him if he could turn it into a chocolate cup.  Well he did, and the result was extraordinary.  It tasted so amazingly natural, so delicious and sweet, that it took everyone by surprise.  It induced an innocent ear-to-ear smile, and it brought his parents to tears the very first time their son took a bite of this delightful new sunflower butter chocolate cup concoction, and voila… Sun Cups were born.

Our Company

At its core, Sun Cups is a chocolate company that focuses on sensational organic nut and gluten-free chocolate products that everyone can enjoy, regardless of allergies. 

We've taken amazing dark and milk chocolate made from organic, equitably sourced Ecuadorian cacao, added our special recipes for roasted sunflower seed  filling, caramel and mint, and created magic in our Nut-Free, Certified Gluten-Free chocolate shop in Boulder, Colorado.  The result is Sun Cups - a healthy indulgence, made from the best stuff on Earth.   We’re organic, safe for people with allergies, and amazingly satisfying for the sweet tooth in all of us!  

Our Mission

Sun Cups lives by the mission to provide both adults and children with a healthier sweet tooth: a chocolate treat of the highest quality, safe for anyone to enjoy.

Sun Cups are peanut-free, gluten-free, tree nut-free, corn-free, soy-free, GMO-free, and Certified Organic chocolate cups.  And they're delicious. 

Simply put, we think we make some of the most mouth-watering chocolate in the world, which is crazy since it’s one of the most health-conscious and safe treats ever created.  (Hard to believe you could put ‘chocolate’ & ‘healthy’ in the same sentence huh?) 

According to FAAN, (Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Network), there are more than 15 million people with food allergies in the US alone, 6 million of which are children.  At our core, this is whom Sun Cups strives to support – the parents who live in fear everyday of the products their child puts into his or her mouth.

Sun Cups gives children with allergies the joy of experiencing a sweet chocolate indulgence, fearlessly.

Your Help 

The  campaign monies will be used to cover the costs needed to produce, ship and deliver Sun Cups to as many of the various food allergy walks and other organizational allergen non-profit events around the country. 

So what do you say? Want to join #SuncupArmy?

It’s time everyone snacks fearlessly.

Sun Cups Superstar - Grand Prize Referral Campaign!

As an added incentive for our campaign, we will be rewarding the person who refers the most number of funders to the campaign with an awesome Grand Prize:

•  A Year’s Supply of Sun Cups!  (5 Master Cases in the flavors of your choice)

•  A personal chocolate-making class with David Lurie, our founder, at the Sun Cups factory* in Boulder, Colorado!

How It Works:

  1. The top referrers will be ranked based on the total number of people they have referred to our campaign and the total dollar amount of contributions raised by these referrals.
  2. To start referring**, share the campaign link (right below the video on the Sun Cups Indiegogo home page) through Facebook, Twitter, Google+, E-Mail, and any other way you can think of to spread the word to your network.  MAKE SURE YOU USE THAT SPECIFIC LINK SO WE CAN TRACK YOUR REFERRALS!

We will publish a regular leaderboard on our update page!

**Important Note: You can only be tracked as a referrer if you are logged into an Indiegogo account when you use any of the “Share Tools” on our campaign. 

Anyone that does not have an Indiegogo account can still have your referrals tracked once you’ve contributed to our campaign. You will be presented with a special URL immediately after contributing (on the completed contribution landing page, under “Spread The Word!”) that you can copy and share with your network.

story:
Who we are

Namaste Indipendent Bookshop was started in boookshop-less little town in 2003 from the dream of two young women with big vision and little money.

From the opening we have striven to create a welcoming venue for cultural and social events, where to feel at “home”

Over the years not only have we sold books. People pop in for a chat, enjoy a tea, meet guest authors, attend herbal medicine courses, take part in writing workshops, drop little ones at the weekly children literature reading.

Unfortunately all of this is ar risk.

Recent competition from Bookstore chains, current economic and cultural crisis, as well as mounting debt  are taking the toll.

Where will the money go?

The funds raised will be partly allocated towards reducing capital debt. The rest will finance all invaluable range of activities at the shop and will allow all our customers to continue enjoy their culture home. 

What are the results?

It is critical for indipendent enterprises such as Namaste to continue operating.They are unique customer experience and they are wealth and treasure of their neighbourood, country, people.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to see The Bookstore continue, please let people know about the store, the campaign, and spread the word. We will post updates about our progress. 

Thank you sincerely,

Francesca&Elisa

www.librerianamaste.it

story:
We are Fare Share Co-op!

And we're on our way to becoming energy efficient, net zero and sustainable. Help us reach our goal to tighten up our building and make our investment in a new heat pump system run as efficiently as possible. 

Why have we begun a path to sustainable energy? 

As a food co-op we work to offer our community healthy food grown sustainably. Part of our mission is to create a sustainable store and in turn a sustainable world. Our building was not lining up with our mission. In fact, our earnings were supporting  giant, rather ugly, antiquated furnaces pumping our dollars out an inefficiently insulated building. 

We are committed to kicking the fossil-fuel habit. By choosing heat pumps, we are now positioned to move more quickly toward using solar power as our energy source. 

Energy Sustainability Plan

  Phase 1: Heat Pumps, LED Lighting, No more Propane and Oil
Investing in electric-fueled heat pumps will save us $4,000 each year in fuel oil costs. Plus, installing LED lights with the help of Efficiency Maine, saves $1,700 each year over our old lighting costs. $20,000.

 Phase 2: Produce Cooler, Insulation, Compressors, Windows
With the help of a USDA grant, installing a new efficient cooler, and the necessary system upgrades, allows us to display more healthy local produce. $5,000

 Phase 3: Repair and Paint Exterior, Insure Roof is Solid
Improving the insulation in the walls and windows will ensure that our heat pumps run efficiently. Repairing and painting the building’s exterior walls and doors will save money and energy, too. $10,000 

 Phase 4: Solar Power!
Finally, we will be ready to install solar panels, the culmination of this long-range project. We want to be the first business in our community to be completely energy self-sufficient and fueled by the sun!

When we add up the costs for Phases 1 through 3, we have determined that $35,000 will allow us to become solar ready. In fact $135,000 would pay for our final goal. 


Savings & Details

To do this, we need help from our membership, our local community, cooperatives and sustainable businesses around the state of Maine and New England, the national co-op community, and national organizations that support the movement toward creating robust local food systems.

Supporting Fare Share Co-op is a vote not only for us to survive, but also to thrive. Since 1978 we have provided an alternative food source to the community and we are now positioned to grow this effort and become a truly sustainable food hub in Western Maine. 


Heat Pumps Our investment of $33,712 in heat pumps will be saving us $4,000 a year in heating costs over our old oil furnaces. To meet our current obligation for this loan from the USDA Rural Development is $12,500.

LED Lights $7,000 worth of LED lighting with the help of Efficiency Maine. Our share of this upgrade is $1,700 of the bill and will be saving $1,700 each year over our old lighting costs.

Produce Cooler A new efficient produce cooler for $12,700 paid for by a USDA grant. The related electrical and condensing unit area upgrades for $4500–$6500. The cooler is long overdue and will help to display more produce.

Insulation $4,000–$6,500 insulates the building (walls and windows) and insures that our new heat pumps are running as efficiently as possible. 

Exterior Repairing and painting the building exterior walls and doors will cost $10,000 and keeps us from having creeping wood rot, and expanding air gaps. 

Management Hiring a general contractor for $2,000 to manage upgrades will allow our General Manager to focus on store operations and continue to move the Co-op towards financial sustainability.


The Impact

With the efforts above we will not only become good stewards of our building and assets, we will also be able to set our sights on Phase 4 of becoming Net Zero by installing a solar energy system or being part of a community solar farm. We've determined that $100,000 more is how much will cost to be energy independent. Daunting but doable!

•  In doing this, we will be a leading model of energy sustainability on Main Street for other businesses, pulling our community as a whole into a more resilient paradigm.

• Becoming energy sustainable will allow us to become operationally sustainable. Dollars earned in the store will not be wasted and will allow us to grow and serve our membership and community.

• Stewardship for our building increases its worth and protects our assets and gives us a stronger position as we move into the future.


History of Fare Share

Fare Share Co-op is an independent member-owned natural food cooperative in historic downtown Norway, Maine. Founded in 1978, Fare Share serves a community with a wide variety of income levels, offering organic and natural foods and products that are locally-sourced, sustainably-produced and ethically-traded. 

Since 2001, after buying and renovating our building, we have become an energetic Main Street anchor that also includes The Commons, a community space that currently houses the Center for Ecology-Based Economy (CEBE), as well as the upstairs rental offices that include Norway Downtown and Western Foothills Land Trust.

Part of our mission is to create a sustainable store and in turn a sustainable world. Our building was not lining up with our mission. In fact, our earnings were supporting  giant, rather ugly, antiquated furnaces and pumping our dollars out a leaky building. Being concerned about the finite resources of our planet, we took steps to audit our energy consumption and needs. The results of the energy audit confirmed that significant changes needed to be made to make us a sustainable and resilient business. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We have laid out all of our costs for this project. Some of those dollars do not need to be spent. Volunteer energy, for example, can handle scraping and painting the building.

If giving or volunteering is still not possible for you, please do this:
Tell your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues about this campaign. 

Spreading this campaign far and wide may touch people that are inspired to help support food co-ops and cooperatives in general in their community and around the nation.

Thank you!

If you have read this far, thank you. Thank you for your time, for your donation and for spreading the word and creating a sustainable co-op and in turn a more sustainable local food system in our community.

Take a look at our video to see our building, our co-op, our membership and our staff in western Maine.

Please share this campaign: igg.me/at/faresharecoop
story_txt:
We are Fare Share Co-op!And we're on our way to becoming energy efficient, net zero and sustainable. Help us
reach our goal to tighten up our building and make our investment in a new heat pump
system run as efficiently as possible. 

Why have we begun a
path to sustainable energy? As a food co-op we work to offer our community
healthy food grown sustainably. Part of our mission is to create a sustainable
store and in turn a sustainable world. Our building was not lining up with our
mission. In fact, our earnings were supporting  giant, rather
ugly, antiquated furnaces pumping our dollars out an inefficiently insulated building. 
We are committed to kicking the fossil-fuel habit. By choosing heat pumps, we are now positioned to move more quickly toward using solar power as our energy source. 
Energy Sustainability Plan
  Phase 1:
Heat Pumps, LED Lighting, No more Propane and OilInvesting
in electric-fueled heat pumps will save us $4,000 each year in fuel oil costs.
Plus, installing LED lights with the help of Efficiency Maine, saves $1,700
each year over our old lighting costs. $20,000.

 Phase 2: Produce
Cooler, Insulation, Compressors, WindowsWith
the help of a USDA grant, installing a new efficient cooler, and the
necessary system upgrades, allows us to display more healthy local produce. $5,000
 Phase 3: Repair
and Paint Exterior, Insure Roof is SolidImproving
the insulation in the walls and windows will ensure that our heat pumps run
efficiently. Repairing
and painting the building’s exterior walls and doors will save money and
energy, too. $10,000 
 Phase 4: Solar Power!Finally,
we will be ready to install solar panels, the culmination of this long-range
project. We want to be the first business in our community to be completely
energy self-sufficient and fueled by the sun!

When
we add up the costs for Phases 1 through 3, we have determined that $35,000 will allow us to become solar
ready. In fact $135,000 would pay for our final goal. 


Savings & Details
To do this, we need help from our membership, our local community, cooperatives and sustainable businesses around the state of Maine and New England, the national co-op community, and national organizations that support the movement toward creating robust local food systems.

Supporting Fare Share Co-op is a vote not only for us to survive, but also to thrive. Since 1978 we have provided an alternative food source to the community and we are now positioned to grow this effort and become a truly sustainable food hub in Western Maine. 


Heat Pumps Our investment of $33,712 in heat pumps will be saving us $4,000 a
year in heating costs over our old oil furnaces. To meet our current obligation for this loan from the USDA Rural Development is $12,500.

LED Lights $7,000 worth
of LED lighting with the help of Efficiency Maine. Our share of this upgrade is $1,700 of the bill and will be saving $1,700 each year over our old lighting costs.
Produce Cooler A new
efficient produce cooler for $12,700 paid for by a USDA grant. The related electrical and condensing unit area upgrades for $4500–$6500. The cooler is long overdue and will help
to display more produce.
Insulation $4,000–$6,500 insulates the building (walls and windows) and insures that our new heat pumps are running as efficiently as possible. 
Exterior Repairing and painting the building exterior walls and doors will cost $10,000 and keeps us from having creeping wood rot, and expanding air gaps. 
Management Hiring a general contractor for $2,000 to manage upgrades will allow our General Manager to focus on store operations and continue to move the Co-op towards financial sustainability.


The ImpactWith the efforts above
we will not only become good stewards of our building and assets, we will also
be able to set our sights on Phase 4 of becoming Net Zero by installing a solar energy system or being part of a community solar farm. We've determined that $100,000 more is how much will cost to be energy independent. Daunting but doable!

•  In doing this, we will be a
leading model of energy sustainability on Main Street for other businesses,
pulling our community as a whole into a more resilient paradigm.

• Stewardship for our building increases its worth and protects our assets and gives us a stronger position as we move into the future.

not lining up with our mission. In fact, our earnings were supporting  giant, rather ugly, antiquated furnaces and pumping our dollars out a
leaky building. Being concerned about the finite resources of our planet, we took steps to audit our energy consumption and needs. The results of the energy audit confirmed that significant changes needed to be made to make us a sustainable and resilient business.

HelpWe have laid out all
of our costs for this project. Some of those dollars do not
need to be spent. Volunteer energy, for example, can handle scraping and
painting the building. If giving or volunteering is still not possible for you,
please do this:Tell your
friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues about this campaign. 
Spreading this
campaign far and wide may touch people that are inspired to help support food
co-ops and cooperatives in general in their community and around the nation.
Thank you!


If you have read this
far, thank you. Thank you for your time, for your donation and for spreading
the word and creating a sustainable co-op and in turn a more sustainable local
food system in our community.

story:
Welcome to my page, I hope you enjoy reading about this exciting vision and the steps to make it achievable.  

About Me...

So firstly, a little about myself for those that don’t know…

My name is Jessica; I’m 27 years old and have been living in Brighton for almost ten years.

In this time I have volunteered for the following:

City Light - a charity working with women who have been trafficked, or who work in the sex industry.

The A21 Campaign - a charity working against the injustice of human trafficking

Safehaven Women - providing a safe space and a hot meal, as well as on-sight beauty treatments for vulnerable women in Brighton and Hove

I have also served as a support worker for homeless young women (16-25yrs) for the last two years. In this time I have had the privilege of helping countless women restore relationships, deal with addictions and get back into safe accommodation.

Before this, I worked in the behavioural department in various secondary schools. In addition to this I have a BA (Hons.) degree in English and Education,  a Level 2 award in Counselling Skills and a vast amount of training around current issues that affect vulnerable people.

About the Vision...

It has become apparent to me that there is a gap in providing safe, ongoing support for women who are victims of sexual abuse and domestic violence (DV). Although Brighton has a host of refuge houses through RISE and other DV charities, there are none that offer long-term accommodation with a holistic approach (offering counselling, teaching and medical care). There are currently only three mainstream women-only houses in Brighton and Hove (band 2, 3 and low support) and only the latter will offer placements to women over 25 years old.

It is my desire that a house may be established which offers higher support and creates a caring family atmosphere, where women can feel they are coming home and not just arriving at a hostel. As part of this, free or discounted counselling (depending on the woman’s financial situation) would be offered for those who are residents there, alongside an array of other services to provide for all of the women's needs.

The hope is to link the project to charities I am currently involved with and with local Churches. There would be an emphasis on encouraging women to explore their own meaning of life and to link in with a local recovery course that has supported so many through their battle over addiction. It may also be the case that others pioneer this project before I am fully qualified, in which case it would be a privilege to be able to join them as a counsellor.

I have already made links concerning funding towards this house and volunteers for the running of it. Please do contact me for more details and I would be happy to answer any questions you may have. Additionally if you are a charity, Church or organisation that would like to be involved in this house in the future or would like my support, please contact me for more details.

What steps must be taken?…

In order to effectively support this service, I am studying a Postgraduate Diploma in Humanistic Psychotherapeutic Counselling at the University of Brighton. In this time I am continuously making links with local charities towards this vision and to help raise funds to see it established. 

I am also working  a part-time job to fund my living costs, which fits around my study, placement and therapy. 

There is no student loan available for counselling post-grad courses and students are expected to fund the course themselves.

What do I need?...

At the moment the main financial help needed is for my course fees, which are £7,000 for the two years. It is also “a requirement that students undertake weekly personal counselling for the duration of the Course” that costs £25 per session.  

Simply put….

WEEKLY:

-£80.50 a week for course fees

-£25 a week for therapy

-£15 a week for travel and materials 

OVERALL FOR TWO YEARS:

-£7,000 for course fees

-£2,600 for therapy

-£1,560 for travel and materials 

TOTAL: £11, 160 

(Please ignore the £12,910... I can't change original figure)


It would be amazing if you could help me to achieve this dream. Even the smallest contribution would be so helpful and so appreciated! 

Please feel free to forward to anyone you know that would like to give towards this long-term goal of mine.

Thank you so much to all my friends, family and St Peter’s Church for the love and encouragement you’ve shown me. I couldn’t do it without you!
