story:
Pop Top Coffee Shop

We are Mandie, Dominic and Golde and we are a little family who hope to make a local coffee joint in Ennis a reality.

When we moved here over a year and half ago after getting hitched in California, we were just two crazy kids who were shocked to learn there was no local coffee spot.  The old historic area seemed like the perfect place for one. We said, 'Someone should really open one up! It would be so great to have a spot to hang out in'.  Soon, those someones became us. Mandie had been tinkering at home for years to create her own coffee recipes and they seemed to be a big hit when she served them to friends and family. When Dominic and Mandie heard about vendors needed at the local Farmer's Market they thought, 'What the heck? Let's try to sell a few!' Through all of the support from amazing Ennis locals, it wasn't long before our humble coffee stand became a hit. We were no longer the "Crazy Californians" but became the "Coffee Couple" (Ennis likes alliteration).  

Pop Top Coffee Shop was born out of a classic 1978 Volkswagen Bus in April 2014. And soon thereafter, so was our mascot/daughter, Golde Rose. Just 6 months later, with perpetually expanding support, our set up became more permanent in the beautiful Ennis National Bank Event Center, where we continue to feel the demand to grow into something larger. The only problem? We don't have all of the funds for that kind of undertaking!

So here's how you can help...

If you want to see a local coffee shop in Historic Downtown Ennis, please contribute! If you can only contribute a little bit, that's great! Every little bit helps. If every one of our Facebook followers contributed just $12.50, we could be funded by tomorrow!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5,000 to fund necessary upgrades to our equipment and building out the coffee shop space. The biggest purchase will be a commercial espresso machine so that we can make all manner of fancy coffees with freshly ground, locally roasted Buna Beans.  If we aren't able to reach our complete goal, we will still be able to purchase things like a new blender, under counter fridge, and commercial pour over coffee maker.

Here are the items and expenses we need to cover:

  • Espresso Machine - La Spaziale S1 Vivaldi II

  • Coffee bean grinder
  • BUNN 12-Cup Pourover Commercial Coffee Brewer
  • Commercial blender
  • Under counter refrigerator 
  • Stainless steel ice bin
  • Cash register
  • Build out of space
We have put tons of time into researching what quality materials we can buy with our relatively small budget and we think with these purchases we can bring a very authentic small coffee shop experience to Ennis. 

But by contributing to our campaign, you not only get to see a local coffee shop grow and thrive to meet your needs and the needs of our community, but you also get some sweet perks like free coffee, free mugs, invites to the Grand Opening, and potentially even your own private parties!

Impact - You, the Community, Your Taste Buds

Imagine a place that you can run in and grab a delicious cup of coffee at a reasonable price on your way to work. Then imagine having a place to hang-out on a Friday evening with a date and/or friends while you enjoy sweet coffee creations in a relaxed atmosphere. We truly think this shop could be a spark to something even larger in our downtown area. We believe in the potential of this town and this area to grow into a gathering place of community and creativity.  

Our vision for the coffee shop focuses on being local. Did you know that Ennis has one of the best locally roasted source of beans in North Texas? Buna Bean serves locations all around the Dallas area and Waxahachie. Yet, there has sadly been no local coffee shop in our town to serve that coffee. Let's take local to the next level! A spot to serve locally roasted coffee, a place to sit down while enjoying a day at the fantastic new Ennis Farmer's Market, a hangout for groups of all kinds.

With a background in non-profit management and now working for the local Catholic church, Dominic knows just how important community is to keeping people healthy and happy. We need our community to bounce ideas off of, support us in the hard times and celebrate with the good. 

Because a warm cup of coffee is sometimes all someone needs to open up to someone else, the coffee shop has proven to be an amazing place to congregate and share our passions, a place to escape for some relaxation, a place to grow together with others, a place for different people to intersect and interact -  church groups, stay-at-home moms, teens to hang out after school. Both Mandie and Dominic have extensive experience hanging out in coffee shops and know just what makes a comfortable relaxing place to relax with a book or a friend.

This Goal of Ours

If we do not manage to reach our goal, we will still be open as our shop is already self-sustaining, but it may be on a part-time basis and the espresso machine will probably have to wait.  We have to purchase some equipment that is absolutely necessary to be a professional coffee shop. 

If we go over our goal, there is plenty of places for that money to go! We would most likely be able to purchase more furniture for sitting areas and decorations to create a more inviting atmosphere. We will already be spending as much of our own money as we can to expand, but every little bit more helps to make us grow that much quicker.

So What's the Challenge?

We are starting small. We won't be open 7 days a week, 12 hours a day any time soon. However, we still think we can give you a great tasting product and keep slowly expanding as our resources allow.

Almost every dollar we make from this coffee shop has been poured directly back into improvements. We have already upgraded and expanded so many items since we started with the coffee shop under the pop-top. Because this is not the primary source of support for our family, reinvesting our profits back into the company is exactly what we plan to do for the foreseeable future.  And then eventually, with your help, maybe all the big ideas we are dreaming about will become reality!

And There Are Other Ways To Help

Share and prayer. These are the two secret weapons of our coffee shop and this campaign. Share as much as you can on social media, your friends, and the people you work with.  Every little bit counts so even if you don't have the funds, you may know several people who may.  And we could always use your prayers so that we know where this coffee shop is headed and do with it as God intends.

Many thanks for all your support so far, it's really appreciated! We really look forward to continuing to serve all of you and helping make our local community more inviting to all!

story:
Who We Are

Vegan Royalty is an apparel company whose mission is to build a peaceable kingdom for all living creatures. Our company is dedicated to bringing forth the positive message of the vegan lifestyle to benefit people, animals, and the planet. All of our products are eco-friendly and a portion of their proceeds will be given back to benefit various local organizations. Here at Vegan Royalty we strive to infuse fun, compassion, sex appeal, and style into all of our products.

Based in Las Vegas, Nevada, Vegan Royalty was founded in March 2014.

Mindy

Founder | Owner | C.E.O.

Mindy combines a cutting edge style to go with a Midwest sensibility. She grew up on a dairy and horse farm in Ohio surrounded by animals. She made her way to Las Vegas seven years ago where she became a vegan. She is the mother of two wonderful children. Mindy is also a partner in Las Vegan Eatz Events and sits on the board of Create A Change Now, educating students about a healthy lifestyle and putting gardens in low income schools. She is in the process of writing her first vegan books for children. 

CAMPAIGN TIME

This campaign is important to us for many reasons. The most significant reason is the ability for us to give back to those non-profits we believe in.  Here at Vegan Royalty we believe true success is measured in personal happiness and the ability to give to those non-profits who are alignment with our mission.

When you contribute to Vegan Royalty you aren't just contributing to a dream of ours, but to the non-profits we believe in. One of those non-profits is an animal sanctuary and the other an organization that helps to put gardens in schools.

To get our profit margins higher, we need to order in higher volume. We are now at the point we need to take this product line to the next level. As the Founder, over the last year, I have worked out the details. I have found the materials, the printers, the embroidery and the designer of logos etc. and produced the website. I have gotten this project as far as I can being a single Mother. I want to truly see the other products come to life.  Your contributions will help us to order more product at one time, in the end get the profit margin higher which will allow us to give back to the non-profits that are in alignment with our mission. We currently are working to give back to two local non-profits. One is an animal sanctuary for farm animals here in Las Vegas and the other places gardens and health & fitness programs in local low income schools. Both of these non-profits are close to our hearts.

Vegan Royalty is also paying a little more to be private labeled. We are very excited to see this come to life as well.

We are also having our Launch Party in Las Vegas the first week in March.  We are getting a lot of the details in line now and some of those details are being donated and some will require a few dollars to make it all go. I am currently working on recycled pieces for the models to wear with the tees and tanks already produced. I would love to have more available not only on our website by then, but in hand to sell that evening for a special price. This Launch Party is going to be a Fashion Show. We have a D.J. donating their time, lights and food and beverage. It will be held at a local art gallery in Downtown Las Vegas. We are looking forward to making this a really big deal. I have experience with event planning and won’t miss a detail! The event will be exposed in the media and be featured in a local style magazine. If we exceed the goal I will but some towards any marketing of the product.

Right now my main hurdle is funds to purchase in higher volume. I feel like I have done the research on most things already and worked out any kinks the last year.

Vegan Royalty feels  your love and wants to give you a little love right back. These are the love levels we would like to extend to you for your contributions:

$20 INSTANTLY RECEIVE GOOD KARMA

$50 INSTANTLY RECEIVE AMAZING KARMA AND A SHOUT OUT ON ALL SOCIAL MEDIA

$150 INSTANTLY RECEIVE AMAZING KARMA, A SOCIAL MEDIA SHOUTOUT AND VEGAN ROYALTY ECO-FRIENDLY VEGGIE TOTE

$500 INSTANTLY RECEIVE AMAZING KARMA,  A SOCIAL MEDIA SHOUTOUT, A VEGAN ROYALTY ECO-FRIENDLY VEGGIE TOTE & TEE, FRONT ROW V.I.P. AT THE VEGAN ROYALTY LAUNCH PARTY WITH CHAMPAGNE AND SPECIAL SHOUT OUTS THAT EVENING.

$1000 INSTANTLY RECEIVE AMAZING KARMA,  A SOCIAL MEDIA SHOUTOUT , 2 VEGAN ROYALTY ECO-FRIENDLY VEGGIE TOTES & 2 TEES AS WELL AS FRONT ROW V.I.P. AT THE VEGAN ROYALTY LAUNCH PARTY WITH CHAMPAGNE AND SPECIAL SHOUT OUTS THAT EVENING. YOU WILL ALSO HAVE CREATIVE INPUT ON THE NEXT TEE OR TANK COLOR SELECTIONS.

I appreciate you listening to my campaign and want to thank you in advance for your contributions and your help to spread the word. I have only a few days to take this to the next level and can’t do it without your help and support. Please LIKE us on Facebook, follow us on Instagram and Twitter. Please stop by our website and use the Indiegogo share tools to help me reach my goal and soar to the place I know I can go.

story:
The Guerrilla Street Food Brick and Mortar

Hello,

We are Brian Hardesty and Joel Crespo.

We own Guerrilla Street Food, St. Louis' first and only Filipino food truck.  Over the last 2 years, we have been working hard to build and maintain a food truck that strives to provide our guests with the best possible experience they can have dining on the street. What you may not know is we have also been planning and working towards building a brick and mortar restaurant.

The demand for our food has been through the roof, especially since appearing on the Food Network show, "Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives." It also didn't hurt that our dish, "The Flying Pig", was named the best dish in St. Louis', over all other restaurants in the city! And now after being named #17 Best Food Truck in the country by Dailymeal.com, we feel that the time is right to push forward and put all of our chips in the middle. It's time for a home for Guerrilla Street Food.

Our Goal is $115,000

We realize that our goal is pretty lofty so, let us break it down for you.

100% of the funding will be going towards renovating and equipping an existing space in the city. We will be updating the exterior, purchasing ovens, sinks, cash registers, building custom equipment like a wood fired Lechon grill, a handmade immersion circulator, signage, etc.


When completed, we will immediately establish ourselves as the finest Filipino Restaurant in the city. You will be able to get your usual food truck favorites at one convenient location, as well as a new expanded menu of dishes what we have not previously been able to offer.  Furthermore, the restaurant will also act as a hub for our food truck and more trucks to come in the future!

If we do not reach our goal, we will hold on to these funds and add to them, via applying for loans, private investors, etc. The plan will then be to reach that goal as soon as we possibly can and move forward with the space.  We will also consider alternative locations that can accommodate our budget if need be.

Guerrilla Street Food has always been the little guy. Our truck was handmade by us and our close friends; getting our hands dirty and calling on the generosity of those that believe us. So, it feels natural to give crowd-source funding a try. Our fans have always been kind to us, as well as honest about what they want to see from us: quality, affordability, and just really good food. I believe we continue to make good on that.  We put our own blood, sweat and tears into this business and so we operate out of a genuine desire to do our best for you all.  And rest assured, we will continue to do so in our restaurant. 

However, we need all of you to make this happen. 
This much we know.  
Let's take GSF to the next level.

If you can't donate, help us spread the word!

One of GSF's greatest strengths is our fanbase. With over 6,000 followers on Twitter and over 4000 on Facebook, it has been relatively easy to promote what we are up to. We plan on using this method for our campaign, and hope you will retweet, share, post, and talk about our endeavor to as many people as you can.

  • Please spread the word as much as possible. It'll help us more than you know.
  • There are share tools on IndieGoGo that should make it easy enough.

Whatever happens, thank you all for your continued support of Guerrilla Street Food. All this love, means the world to us. We want to keep moving this business forward, with your help.

story:
My name is Melyssa Flynn and I am a 17 year old junior cyclist with a lung disease. Cycling is one of my biggest passions and over the years has kept me healthy.

In early 2010 I was diagnosed with Bronchiectasis, Polysplenia and an abnormal heart. Since then my family have made it our goal to raise as much money and assist as much as we can with LIWA (Lung Institue of Western Australia). Delirium 24 Hour in Cowaramup is one way which we have been able to do this. 

On April 20th I will be gearing  up to ride for 12 hours on a 3.7km circuit in Cowaramup. This is not only a mental challenge but a physical challenge. This will be the toughest race of my life but nothing compared to the life that a person who was diagnosed too late with chronic lung disease will live. I was lucky to have early diagnosis and have taken it upon myself to help others too.

This year my goal is to raise at least $3000 to give back to the Lung Institue (LIWA) to not only help with research, but to give other kids my age a chance to have a healthier future like I was able to thanks to others who fundraised. 

All donations will be given to LIWA to assist in research, training and funding for facilities in regional areas.

Next year I aim to do bigger and better by doing the 24 Hour solo and doubling the fundraising. Throughout this year I will also be participating in other events where I will be fundraising for LIWA.

If you are not able to donate that is understandable but please spread the word out about my cause. As a community we can help raise money and help LIWA carry on their fantastic work within the Western Australia community.

story:
Our Story

 

Karma Coffee Shop is a independently owned coffee shop located in Wayne, MI. We have been in business since 2010 and have created a haven for people young and old, in a city where there previously was none.

We have live music every weekend for only the price of a drink and open mic on Tuesdays which has become a staple for many. Karma hosts many events and shows enabling locals to display their talents where they may not have had an outlet.

 

In June of 2011, we were informed that our lease would not be renewed and would have to find a new location.

This has caused our shop to be closed untill we find a new building. By having to move so suddenly we were not prepared to start over and rebuild a store front from scratch.

Luckily we have found a possible new building and would like to move in soon, but we need funding.

 

A coffee shop makes a city, it gives a place to relax, meet with friends, enjoy music, or just work in a different location. Help our city get its beloved Karma Coffee Shop back. It would mean the world to us.

 

 

The Impact

 

Karma Coffee Shop has become a home away from home for our customers. We create all our drinks with love and know the majority of our customers by name or favorite drink.

 

We believe that every city needs a coffee shop and want to reopen Karma Coffee Shop and bring our ideas back to life.

Without out Karma Coffee reopening in Wayne, where will aspiring artists and budding musicans go to showcase there talent? The impact will be devistating to our customers and to us. We believe in bringing the arts and a feeling of a home away from home to the people.

 

Please help our Baristas get back to work and let us give our city a nice place to hang out.

If we are unable to get enough funds we will be forced to stay closed permantly.

This is not an option that we or our customers are comfortable with.

 

Doesn't everyone need an independent coffee shop in their town?

What We Need & What You Get

 

To reopen Karma we will need around $3,000 to pay for city fees, lease down payment, supplies,and misc costs associated with opening.

 

Since Karma has been an established business for over a year and a half, we do not need to buy equipment,counters, tables, etc associated with running a coffee shop. We have all of these items already in storage and waiting for a new home.

 

 Thanks to our wonderful customers we recieved a nice donation towards our moving costs, but we still need more.

This is where you can help! Any amount you can help with will be put to good use towards opening our new doors!

 

For your kind donation you will recieve once we open:

 

$5 -      A hand written letter of gratitude from our staff and a Karma Coffee Shop bumper sticker and shout out 

            on our facebook page and website!

$10 -     A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee.

$25-     A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee, and a $20 gift

            card.

$50-      A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee,$50 gift card.

$100-    A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee, and a $100

              gift card.

$500-    A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee,Barista for

             a  day

$1000 - A hand written letter of gratitude, Karma bumper sticker, Shout outs, and a bag of coffee, Barista for

              a day and a private party for you and up to 80 friends.

            

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate we still can use your help!

If you could please tell your friends about our cause.

Also we can always use some muscle moving things from storage to the new location.

Just email us how you would like to help out!

Thanks in advance

story:
Hi,

My name is Gagara K. Abdou. I am the Executive Director of The Kirker African Medical Relief Association (KAMRA). 

About the Organization – KAMRA:

KAMRA is a 501(c)3 charitable organization established in the State of South Carolina in 2007. KAMRA works to improve the quality of life in Africa through good health and education. It is dedicated to the relief of pain, suffering and illnesses on the Continent of Africa and works to achieve these ideals by providing those less fortunate and in need of assistance, with modern medical care and services. KAMRA receives medicines, medical supplies and equipment from US partners, mainly MAP International and MedShare and then ships then to Africa. We currently intervene in Niger, one of the poorest countries in the world according the United Nations Development Index.

KAMRA equally dedicates itself to providing educational opportunities to young boys and girls without any present chance at schooling. This is achieved through furnishing modern learning centers. These centers provide buildings, teachers, computers, books, pencils, paper, recreational equipment, supplies and materials of all kinds, necessary to the needs of running a modern learning institution. 

What we accomplished so far:

Since its inception in 2007, KAMRA has arranged for and facilitated the shipment of more than $30 million worth of medicines, medical supplies and equipment, and schoolbooks and supplies to Niger, West Africa. 

About this Specific Project:

This Kirker Hospital Support Project is specifically designed to sponsor and ship a 40ft container of Medicines to Niger. These medicines will benefit not only the Kirker Hospital of Maine Soroa, but also to other health facilities in Niger.

KAMRA needs to raise $25,000 from this campaign to be able to sponsor and ship the 40ft container of medicines, which is worth more than $1,000,000.00. The medicines are donated by MAP International.

$1.00 donated equals $40.00 of medicines shipped.

Why you should support this Project:

One hundred percent of donation will be used to ship much need medicines to people who otherwise will have no access to them.

More information on our organization and work, including our 501©3 status can be found on our website: http://kirkerfoundation.org

story:
Hi! This is me. My name is Rens Pothuizen. I am 27 years young and live in a tiny village in the middle of Holland where everything is as flat as can be. My dream is to start up a business in a whole different landscape: near the foothills of the Himalaya in Kathmandu. Why you ask? Please allow me to tell you a bit more and I'll even answer the what, who and when. 

Why?

It’s not that I just woke up one day and thought: “You know what would be nice? Let’s go to the other end of the world and start up a business there!” No, I’ve already been to Nepal quite a few times over the years.

During my first stay I did some volunteer work teaching English at a tiny school. I met the most wonderful people over there (but more about them at the who-part) and had the time of my life. Two years later I started an organization called Fair Chance with some friends of mine. Fair Chance helps underprivileged children through school and college in Nepal. When we started out we had just 4 boys in school, now we are already up to 50 kids!

I love Nepal and the people over there. I would love to be able to spend more time there and it is possible. Nepal is wedged in between India and Chine, two of the biggest emerging markets in the world. The Nepali economy is also growing at a quick pace. Even though Nepal is still a 3rd world country, things are changing quickly. In 2001 over 55% of the population still had to live on less than $1 a day. That number has dropped to about 19% in 2010 and it’s still declining! Nepal’s middle class is growing rapidly. More and more people have a little extra to spend, which brings us to the what.      

What?

Laser tag! What? Yes, you heard me: laser tag. As I said the Nepali middle class is growing rapidly. More and more people have some money to spend in their free time. Right now there aren’t that many options for Nepalis to choose from. There are a handful of big cinemas who have about 200.000 visitors a month. Other than that there are just a few bowling alleys and a buck load of cheap bars, but that’s about it.

So laser tag! The Roswell Incident will be the very first laser tag arena in Nepal. Laser tag is a popular game all over the world. The game is comparable to paintball, but instead of firing balls of paint people wear vests with hit points and shoot with laser guns. Laser tag is being played in an indoor arena. To create an incredible experience for the players, the arena is filled up with fog, black light and all kinds of funky decorations.

This ‘product’ is the first thing that will set us aside from our competition. We have plans to build a laser tag center, complete with bar in American ’60 Diner style, instruction- and vesting area and of course a 300 square meter laser tag arena that will be big enough for 20 players at a time.

The second thing that will set us aside is quality. In Nepal things have ‘the tendency to break down’. Whenever you are out to enjoy yourself, something is about to break. It’s a major pain in the *ss. What will set us aside from the competition is good quality equipment. The laser tag equipment that we’ll use has been build according to the highest standards in the business. It can be run over by a truck and will still work!

Third is service. Once you enter The Roswell Incident you will feel welcome. The staff will be very friendly and you’ll immediately feel like you belong.

Who?

I won’t be running this business alone, two very dear friends of mine will help me out. Let me introduce you to them as well:

Uttam

First up is Uttam. Uttam is 19 and has lived in Kathmandu his whole life. He hasn't had a very good start in life. His family has been falling apart pretty much from the day that he was born. His father left the family when Uttam was still very young. Uttam’s older brother left too when Uttam was just 9 years old. At that point his mother made him quit school and start looking for work. He ended up on the streets of Thamel selling self-made drawings to tourists.

Uttam was 12 years old when he went to the zoo one day with two of his closest friends. At 5:00 pm the boys returned home, where Uttam got the shock of a lifetime. When he opened the door of his apartment all was gone. The only things that remained were his clothes and a bed. The lady next door had to tell him that his mother had left with her boyfriend to go live with him. His mother said Uttam was old enough to take care of himself. At the age of 12, Uttam was all alone.

He didn’t have time to realize what had happened. He just went back to drawing pictures and selling them the very next day. He managed to collect enough money to stay alive for about a month. That’s when I ran into him. We started a conversation and it didn’t take him long to explain what had happened to him. I felt sorry for him and wanted to help out. Luckily I would be in Nepal for another 5 months. I helped Uttam move to a new place where the father of his best friend agreed to keep an eye on him. Also Uttam went back to school again for the first time in 3 years.

Uttam is now 19. He did very well in school and passed his high school exams with flying colors. At the moment he’s studying Management at a college in Kathmandu. He’s living together with his girlfriend and enjoys life every day. His big dream is becoming independent. Starting a business is his way of doing that. A dream that you can now help him with.     

Sunil

The third partner in this venture is Sunil (20). His start in life also wasn’t optimal. Sunil actually lived on the streets as a street kid for quite some time when he was about 11 years old.

When I met Sunil he was living on the street. One day I was waiting for a traffic light with a friend of mine. Two young boys appeared out of nowhere and jumped on the back of our bikes. They ‘ordered’ us to start driving. When the traffic light turned green, there was not much else we could do. The two kids had the time of their life back there and after a kilometer or so they jumped of and ran back in the direction where we came from.

That night I walked through the city on my way to a bar. In a narrow alley I saw a kid going through some trash, looking for something to eat. When I came closer I noticed it was the same kid that had sat on the back of my bike that very morning. That’s how I met Sunil. 

Sunil hang around for a few more months. When I had to go back home, I couldn’t leave Sunil there on the streets. Through a French organization I was able to put Sunil in a child home. I became his sponsor and we stayed in touch.  

In the home Sunil got the chance to go back to school again. An opportunity he grabbed tight with both hands. Sunil passed his high school exam last year and is now in college. His big dream is to be independent as well. He wants to be able to help out others that are in the same situation as he has been in. He sees this business as his opportunity to fulfill his dreams.

When?

If all goes to plan, it should take about a year before The Roswell Incident will open its doors. Our goal is to open our doors in October 2013, right around the Nepali festival season. But before we can even think about opening, there are a million things to take care of. Some of which, you could help us out with…

What we need

What we need most of all is money. Hopefully with your help we can reach our goal of $20.000 at Indiegogo. If you think that $20.000 isn't enough money to start a laser tag arena you would be completely right: it won't be enough. In total we will roughly need $180.000.

It will however be a huge step forward for us in accomplishing our goals. This first $20.000 will enable us to register our company in Nepal (the amount of $20.000 is the minimum amount required by Nepali law for a foreign investment in an existing company). 

Further, we will use the money to secure the rest of our funding. Once we have our first investment, it will be easier for others to follow. Other investors will be more likely to pitch in. Having capital already also will make it a whole lot easier getting a loan from the bank (especially in these days).

If you want to know exactly how we will spend the money once we are fully funded, please feel free to contact us. We can tell you all about our financial plans in detail, but don't want to bother everyone with this boring info ;-)

How you can help

With money
First of all: make a contribution! For our plans to become a reality we need money. Simple as that. Look through our perks and pick your favorite that suits your budget.

Without money
Of course we know that not everybody can make a contribution. Luckily there are other ways to help us as well. Everyone can help us out by making noise! We don’t mean that you have to scream in your neighbors ear, but you can like, comment and share our campaign with all your friends on facebook, so our campaing hits it big on social media. 

Last but not least: if you have a good idea or knows some tips or tricks for us, please feel free to contact us at any time. We would be glad to hear you out. Anything that could help us is welcome!

That number has dropped to about 19% in 2010 and it’s still declining! Nepal’s middle class is growing rapidly. More and more people have a little extra to spend, which brings us to the what.      
What?
Laser tag! What? Yes, you heard me: laser tag. As I said the Nepali middle class is growing rapidly. More and more people have some money to spend in their free time. Right now there aren’t that many options for Nepalis to choose from. There are a handful of big cinemas who have about 200.000 visitors a month. Other than that there are just a few bowling alleys and a buck load of cheap bars, but that’s about it.

So laser tag! The Roswell Incident will be the very first laser tag arena in Nepal. Laser tag is a popular game all over the world. The game is comparable to paintball, but instead of firing balls of paint people wear vests with hit points and shoot with laser guns. Laser tag is being played in an indoor arena. To create an incredible experience for the players, the arena is filled up with fog, black light and all kinds of funky decorations.
This ‘product’ is the first thing that will set us aside from our competition. We have plans to build a laser tag center, complete with bar in American ’60 Diner style, instruction- and vesting area and of course a 300 square meter laser tag arena that will be big enough for 20 players at a time.
The second thing that will set us aside is quality. In Nepal things have ‘the tendency to break down’. Whenever you are out to enjoy yourself, something is about to break. It’s a major pain in the *ss. What will set us aside from the competition is good quality equipment. The laser tag equipment that we’ll use has been build according to the highest standards in the business. It can be run over by a truck and will still work!
Third is service. Once you enter The Roswell Incident you will feel welcome. The staff will be very friendly and you’ll immediately feel like you belong.

Who?
I won’t be running this business alone, two very dear friends of mine will help me out. Let me introduce you to them as well:
UttamFirst up is Uttam. Uttam is 19 and has lived in Kathmandu his whole life. He hasn't had a very good start in life. His family has been falling apart pretty much from the day that he was born. His father left the family when Uttam was still very young. Uttam’s older brother left too when Uttam was just 9 years old. At that point his mother made him quit school and start looking for work. He ended up on the streets of Thamel selling self-made drawings to tourists.
Uttam was 12 years old when he went to the zoo one day with two of his closest friends. At 5:00 pm the boys returned home, where Uttam got the shock of a lifetime. When he opened the door of his apartment all was gone. The only things that remained were his clothes and a bed. The lady next door had to tell him that his mother had left with her boyfriend to go live with him. His mother said Uttam was old enough to take care of himself. At the age of 12, Uttam was all alone.

He didn’t have time to realize what had happened. He just went back to drawing pictures and selling them the very next day. He managed to collect enough money to stay alive for about a month. That’s when I ran into him. We started a conversation and it didn’t take him long to explain what had happened to him. I felt sorry for him and wanted to help out. Luckily I would be in Nepal for another 5 months. I helped Uttam move to a new place where the father of his best friend agreed to keep an eye on him. Also Uttam went back to school again for the first time in 3 years.
Uttam is now 19. He did very well in school and passed his high school exams with flying colors. At the moment he’s studying Management at a college in Kathmandu. He’s living together with his girlfriend and enjoys life every day. His big dream is becoming independent. Starting a business is his way of doing that. A dream that you can now help him with.     
Sunil
The third partner in this venture is Sunil (20). His start in life also wasn’t optimal. Sunil actually lived on the streets as a street kid for quite some time when he was about 11 years old.
When I met Sunil he was living on the street. One day I was waiting for a traffic light with a friend of mine. Two young boys appeared out of nowhere and jumped on the back of our bikes. They ‘ordered’ us to start driving. When the traffic light turned green, there was not much else we could do. The two kids had the time of their life back there and after a kilometer or so they jumped of and ran back in the direction where we came from.
That night I walked through the city on my way to a bar. In a narrow alley I saw a kid going through some trash, looking for something to eat. When I came closer I noticed it was the same kid that had sat on the back of my bike that very morning. That’s how I met Sunil. 
Sunil hang around for a few more months. When I had to go back home, I couldn’t leave Sunil there on the streets. Through a French organization I was able to put Sunil in a child home. I became his sponsor and we stayed in touch.  
In the home Sunil got the chance to go back to school again. An opportunity he grabbed tight with both hands. Sunil passed his high school exam last year and is now in college. His big dream is to be independent as well. He wants to be able to help out others that are in the same situation as he has been in. He sees this business as his opportunity to fulfill his dreams.
When?
If all goes to plan, it should take about a year before The Roswell Incident will open its doors. Our goal is to open our doors in October 2013, right around the Nepali festival season. But before we can even think about opening, there are a million things to take care of. Some of which, you could help us out with…

What we need
What we need most of all is money. Hopefully with your help we can reach our goal of $20.000 at Indiegogo. If you think that $20.000 isn't enough money to start a laser tag arena you would be completely right: it won't be enough. In total we will roughly need $180.000.
It will however be a huge step forward for us in accomplishing our goals. This first $20.000 will enable us to register our company in Nepal (the amount of $20.000 is the minimum amount required by Nepali law for a foreign investment in an existing company). 
Further, we will use the money to secure the rest of our funding. Once we have our first investment, it will be easier for others to follow. Other investors will be more likely to pitch in. Having capital already also will make it a whole lot easier getting a loan from the bank (especially in these days).
If you want to know exactly how we will spend the money once we are fully funded, please feel free to contact us. We can tell you all about our financial plans in detail, but don't want to bother everyone with this boring info ;-)
How you can help
With money First of all: make a contribution! For our plans to become a reality we need money. Simple as that. Look through our perks and pick your favorite that suits your budget.
Without money Of course we know that not everybody can make a contribution. Luckily there are other ways to help us as well. Everyone can help us out by making noise! We don’t mean that you have to scream in your neighbors ear, but you can like, comment and share our campaign with all your friends on facebook, so our campaing hits it big on social media. 

Last but not least: if you have a good idea or knows some tips or tricks for us, please feel free to contact us at any time. We would be glad to hear you out. Anything that could help us is welcome!

story:
Hi. My name is Andie Flores, I'm a senior at Barrett the Honors College at Arizona State University. I major in Design Studies, with a minor in Communication, and am currently working on my senior honors thesis/creative project. I would love for you to help me make my dream (and project) a reality that lives far past my senior year.


My project—currently named Força (which is Portuguese for "strength" and slang for "kickass")—is to develop a fully-functioning, community-building, website that features contributions in the form of essays, articles, videos, slideshows, and more from all kinds of artists, musicians, journalists, independent thinkers, activists, writers, and influential people of all sorts of varying ethnicities and backgrounds. The dream is for it to be a fashion, arts, music, culture, important issues and news site that is directed toward younger people of color. A place for young adults to get a solid grasp of amazing work being done in various fields around the country (and ideally, around the world) by other people of color. The target audiences for the site are the many groups of people who are otherwise underrepresented or misrepresented and otherized in mainstream news— and sometimes even alternative news. The site’s purpose is not only be showcase talent and conversations from a range of ethnicities, but also to be extremely inclusive of other groups of people whose voices are largely muted or underrepresented (LGBT community, etc.).

Many sites, like Latina Magazine and Ebony.com, offer news to smaller minority groups, but don't attempt to bridge multiplicities of identities. My ultimate goal is this: to build a website that will be updated daily, and present information and viewpoints that are not only beneficial to communities of minorities, but to everyone. I want to create a non-otherized space for normally otherized people, a place where they are inspired to be big, to build networks, to understand that their goals and dreams and desires for their futures are all not only valid and worthwhile, but also supported and strongly encouraged. This site is for young adults growing up in a world that tries to tell us what we need and who we are, instead of encouraging us to define those needs and understandings.

The main goal? To create a generation-oriented culture map that works to foster developing identities of young adults of color by encompassing a wide range of underrepresented voices and viewpoints in hopes of instilling pride, passion, and a willingness to succeed in its audiences.

Why is this important? The site will give the multiplicity of our identities as people of color, or as otherized people—and not simply the otherized and stereotyped ones portrayed in the mainstream media—a place to navigate and heal through the trauma induced by the forced simplification, deconstruction, and reconstruction of our identities to the expectations of mainstream culture.

Breakdown of Expenses:

What we need now are funds to get this site online, pay for site hosting and our domain name, web design, photography, content, and future incentives for contributors. My goal is $700. It sounds like a lot, but if 140 of you donate $5, we can make it. If we raised more, it would be amazing, but right now I would just love to have enough to cover the costs to get the basics running. Can't contribute? Share! The more people who know about this, the better!

If you help donate, you aren’t just contributing to MY vision. You’re helping to build a community of people trying to build a better (and more dialogue rich) world for all of us.

If you have questions or would like ot get involved, feel free to email me at andaleandie@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary


The Central Florida Dreamplex, which opens its doors September, 2014, will provide opportunities for physical fitness, social interaction, employment, inclusion, and fun for children and adults with disabilities.


Eventually, the Dreamplex will be housed in a 100,000-square-foot multiple-venue facility that will offer programming in a variety of athletic competitions, adaptive sports, and alternative therapies. The facility opening this fall is much smaller,  but will have just as big an impact on its users. 

The idea for the Dreamplex formed when a local pediatric therapy group noticed the lack of opportunities available to its aged-out clients for social involvement and physical fitness.  They wanted to create something that would help fulfill the needs of their clients: a place to achieve health and wellness, a place for social interaction, and a place of employment.  

Central Florida Pediatric Therapy Foundation was formed in 2009, and has since been addressing various needs of the disabled population while working towards its long-term vision of building the Central Florida Dreamplex. 

In an effort to both effectively serve our clients AND continue towards developing the larger final product, we are moving forward with opening a smaller version that will serve as a "welcome center" to introduce our vision of the larger facility and will allow us to grow our programs and serve a larger audience.  This smaller venue is scheduled to open in September, 2014 in Clermont, FL.  It will include a fitness center with "total access" capabilities designed for users with disabilities and special needs.  It will also house our ballet/dance and Tae Kwon Do classes for children with special needs.  Suspended gymnastics equipment, a rock wall, and other specialized equipment will be utilized for alternative therapies.

The Central Florida Dreamplex, in its eventual larger state or the more-imminent smaller state, will be "home" to many families to collaborate and offer each other support.  Membership at our facility will mean so much than a place to work out; it will be a larger family where ideas, struggles, and accomplishments will be shared!

What We Need & What You Get

As with any new venture, our 501(c)3 faces many start-up costs.  We must complete the build-out of our leased space, install rubberized flooring, and purchase equipment.  For this campaign, we are focused solely on purchasing the specialized equipment that allows for total access to all users.  Our first priorities are the rock wall, gymnastics equipment, and three specialized cardio-workout machines.  Whether we fall short of our goal, or far exceed it, all funds will go towards providing the best equipment available for our members.  Your contribution will allow us to offer this equipment while keeping costs minimal to our members.

The Impact

Special needs children/youth/adults are often left out of many activities that able-bodied individuals take for granted.  On Saturday morning, for instance, when many children head out to play football, basketball or soccer, special needs kids and their families sit at home, isolated.  The Dreamplex will change that.  The ultimate goal is to build a 100,000 sq ft facility on land (already donated) in Wellness Way, just south of Clermont, FL.  The infrastructure for that property will not be in place until about 2016, so the Foundation has decided to open an interim facility to begin providing services immediately.  Although it will not have all the bells and whistles of the ultimate Dreamplex, it will provide a venue for Tae Kwon Do, Ballet, rock-climbing wall, gymnastic and suspended equipment and various workout machines geared toward the special needs population.

Children with autism and sensory integration deficits benefit from suspended equipment because they seek sensory input.  Gymnastic equipment and bikes that target upper body muscles while others work out lower body will be connected to X-box games to bring out the fun while working out specific muscle groups.

Participating in these activities will help children/youth develop confidence, fitness and sense of well-being and inclusion.  

The target population for the Dreamplex is disabled children and adults living in Lake County, Orange County, and beyond.  In 2013, there were 2,477 children under the age of 18 who had one or more disabilities, according to  Quality of Life: A Snapshot of Lake County 2013.  Although the program will be located in south Lake County, it is hoped that many children with disabilities from throughout the county and surrounding areas will participate, due to its unique nature.  

The program will benefit children with disabilities by giving them a place to improve their muscle tone by exercising on adaptive equipment, build friendships with other children, develop self-confidence and have fun.  Although having fun might seem trivial, fun is sometimes woefully lacking in the lives of disabled children.

In addition, the Dreamplex will provide a place where parents of disabled children can interact with other parents whose children face similar difficulties in life.  Often these parents can become isolated and the Dreamplex will allow them to share ideas and camaraderie.

At the Central Fl Dreamplex in Clermont, children with disabilities will walk on balance beams, climb a rock-wall, tap moving lights on a light wall, jump on a trampoline and swing from the ceiling on suspended exercise equipment.  At the same time, other disabled children will play on exercise bikes with integrated Xbox or Nintendo games, which will challenge them physically and hold their interest while they pedal with their hands or feet.  In another area of fitness, patient and entertaining instructors will teach children how to perform ballet or Tae Kwon Do.  

The Central Florida Dreamplex will collaborate with entities such as Building Blocks Ministry, Special Olympics, CARD and New Vision for Independence. Part of this collaboration will consist of receiving referrals for the various agencies' clients, as well as providing a new resource for them to use.  In addition, the Dreamplex will hire disabled adults and teen-agers to work in its planned snack bar or in other appropriate jobs.

The program is significant because it provides services unlike any other venue in Central Florida.  Although other programs provide job skills or therapy, the Dreamplex provides a place for the disabled population to maintain or improve their health, socialize with others with disabilities, work, learn new skills and have fun.

Successful Track Record:

The Dreamplex executive director, Amy Gomes, has had a great deal of experience in program design and implementation.  In 2010, she opened a school for disabled children in Ukraine, procuring funds, developing and constructing a facility and hiring a director.  In addition, Ms. Gomes owns and runs a successful pediatric therapy business, Central Florida Pediatric Therapy Associates, for the past 23 years.

Ms. Gomes son, Cameron, will manage the day to day operations at the Dreamplex.  He graduated Summa Cum Laude in business from the University of Central Florida and holds a Masters degree in Business from Florida Institute of Technology.  He spent several years at Lockheed Martin and is currently working at an ice-skating rink in Kansas City, KS to gain the experience he will need to run the Dreamplex.  He and his wife, Sarah, will relocate to Central Florida prior to the opening of the Dreamplex.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are plenty of ways to help us in our efforts!

  • Share our campaign and/or our video to spread our vision!
  • Like our facebook page! (www.facebook.com/cfldreamplex)
  • View our website for more information (www.cfldreamplex.com)
  • Contact the city of Clermont, FL and Lake County, FL to voice your support!
  • Talk to businesses about becoming a sponsor!  Sponsors will receive recognition at our facility!
  • Join our newsletter to stay up-to-date on our progress and participate in our golf tournament, 5k, and dinner fundraisers! (sign up at www.faithprojects.org)

story:
The purpose of this campaign is to support Cuy Incaico, an association of guinea pig (Cuy, pronounced coo-wey) producers in Cusco, Peru that the nonprofit, ProWorld Peru has identified as a organization worthy of help. Cuy Incaico helps support 124 women and their families through a collaborative network, in which the ladies share best practices and their experiences relating to the production of guinea pigs for human consumption. Currently the association helps provide education, training, distribution channels, and marketing. The women involved in this association are trying to provide for their families on less than $3/day and this campaign provides an opportunity to raise their standard of living. 

Cuy meat provides half of the needed daily protein for Peruvians, and has more protein and less cholesterol than beef, pork, or chicken. The fundraiser will provide Cuy Incaico funds to purchase food grinding equipment that processes soy, corn, alfalfa, minerals/vitamins, and other ingredients that the Cuy consume. Currently the women are struggling to find a mixed feed product, but they can find the raw materials to produce a consistent high quality feed at a lower cost. The equipment will allow the women to be more efficient and the additional money will assist the association buy raw materials in bulk, which will help the women secure a discount and lower overall feed costs.

We are graduate students studying abroad through the MBA program at the University of Denver - Daniels College of Business and the International Affairs and Global Enterprise program at the University of Utah. Our mission is to work collaboratively with the established Cuy farm association to provide the grinding equipment and the start up ingredients to cut costs and improve production according to the following business plan. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are seeking to raise $2,700.00 to cover the procurement of a grinding machine (moleador) and a mixer (mescaldor) from a local Peruvian farm equipment manufacturing company.
  • $3,300 will provide a seed fund to help launch the operations and specifically the procurement of raw materials involved in producing the Cuy food
  • ProWorld Peru and our team will provide updates on their progress and outcomes.

The Impact

  • This project will result in a standardized high quality food. The increased nutritional value will lead to increased growth and higher sales prices. 

  • We estimate that profits will increase from $3.75 to  $5.13 per guinea pig produced. This 37 percent increase will empower these women to better provide for their families. For example, the Yupa family currently earns $187.50/month and under this new model this amount would increase to $256.50. This extra $69 is enough to provide a family of three with an entire months worth of food.

Risks & Challenges

  • We realize that this group is new to formal business plans, so we have enlisted the aid of ProWorld Peru, which will be on the ground assisting the association every step of the way. The leadership of Cuy Incaico is highly experienced in managing operations related to social enterprise, having served in the presidency of a government child welfare program (food distribution). 

  • Early on we realized that the organization needed to identify a location that was owned and operated by the organization versus a space owned by a individual member. Our model includes the expenses of the rent and the salary for an employee to operate the machinery. We feel this helps reduce the potential risk of misuse significantly.

  • We used very conservative estimates to determine decreases in costs and increases in profits. We collected extensive data on every member of the association to capture a precise picture of the current economic situation, and feel that our analysis is comprehensive and supports a strong business case. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are unable to contribute financially to this project, please share with your friends and family to help spread the word about Cuy Incaico. Every little bit will help us reach our goal and stateside support will be invaluable. We want to share this experience with you, as well, so keep posted on our facebook page and check in often

  • Once we reach our goal, we will be posting updates on how this has greatly helped Cuy Incaico achieve their vision at www.facebook.com/cuyincaico.

  • Also please take some time to learn more about Pro World Peru at: ProWorld Peru
  • Please feel free to comment below with any questions or contact us at Cory.McClellan@gmail.com for a personal response.

Currently the association helps provide education, training, distribution channels, and marketing. The women involved in this association are trying to provide for their families on less than $3/day and this campaign provides an opportunity to raise their standard of living. 
Cuy meat provides half of the needed daily protein for Peruvians, and has more protein and less cholesterol than beef, pork, or chicken. The fundraiser will provide Cuy Incaico funds to purchase food grinding equipment that processes soy, corn, alfalfa, minerals/vitamins, and other ingredients that the Cuy consume. Currently the women are struggling to find a mixed feed product, but they can find the raw materials to produce a consistent high quality feed at a lower cost. The equipment will allow the women to be more efficient and the additional money will assist the association buy raw materials in bulk, which will help the women secure a discount and lower overall feed costs.
We are graduate students studying abroad through the MBA program at the University of Denver - Daniels College of Business and the International Affairs and Global Enterprise program at the University of Utah. Our mission is to work collaboratively with the established Cuy farm association to provide the grinding equipment and the start up ingredients to cut costs and improve production according to the following business plan. What We Need & What You Get
We are seeking to raise $2,700.00 to cover the procurement of a grinding machine (moleador) and a mixer (mescaldor) from a local Peruvian farm equipment manufacturing company.
$3,300 will provide a seed fund to help launch the operations and specifically the procurement of raw materials involved in producing the Cuy food
ProWorld Peru and our team will provide updates on their progress and outcomes.

The Impact
This project will result in a standardized high quality food. The increased nutritional value will lead to increased growth and higher sales prices. 

We estimate that profits will increase from $3.75 to  $5.13 per guinea pig produced. This 37 percent increase will empower these women to better provide for their families. For example, the Yupa family currently earns $187.50/month and under this new model this amount would increase to $256.50. This extra $69 is enough to provide a family of three with an entire months worth of food.

Risks & Challenges
We realize that this group is new to formal business plans, so we have enlisted the aid of ProWorld Peru, which will be on the ground assisting the association every step of the way. The leadership of Cuy Incaico is highly experienced in managing operations related to social enterprise, having served in the presidency of a government child welfare program (food distribution). 
Early on we realized that the organization needed to identify a location that was owned and operated by the organization versus a space owned by a individual member. Our model includes the expenses of the rent and the salary for an employee to operate the machinery. We feel this helps reduce the potential risk of misuse significantly.
We used very conservative estimates to determine decreases in costs and increases in profits. We collected extensive data on every member of the association to capture a precise picture of the current economic situation, and feel that our analysis is comprehensive and supports a strong business case. 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute financially to this project, please share with your friends and family to help spread the word about Cuy Incaico. Every little bit will help us reach our goal and stateside support will be invaluable. We want to share this experience with you, as well, so keep posted on our facebook page and check in often
Once we reach our goal, we will be posting updates on how this has greatly helped Cuy Incaico achieve their vision at www.facebook.com/cuyincaico.
Also please take some time to learn more about Pro World Peru at: ProWorld Peru



Please feel free to comment below with any questions or contact us at Cory.McClellan@gmail.com for a personal response.

story:
What We're Doing. 

We are Basic Training, a San Francisco-based outdoor fitness company, and we are installing an outdoor workout space for public use in Hayes Valley. The free, pop-up  fitness hub will transform a previously unused parking lot within Hayes Valley's PROXY project into a bright, colorful, beautifully designed multi-use space (see below!)

Everyone knows we spend too much time tied to our desks and computers, but breaking these habits can be tough. The Basic Training fitness hub is an innovative answer to the problems city dwellers face when there are few, if any, open-air fitness options outside their door or office. This "hub" will be a place where people can mix things up on their way to and from work by jumping, climbing, swinging, running, pushing, playing, or simply pondering the possibilities of free, unfettered, activity for all -- 24 hours a day.

As California Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom put it, "This communal facility provides a blueprint for a healthy, livable, and vibrant community."


Why Us. 

Basic Training has been leading people on adventures across San Francisco’s varied natural terrain and breathtaking landmarks for five years. No one knows her curves and contours as well as we do. But there are places in the city where access to this terrain is not immediate, and there are times (like on a lunch break from work or on your way home) when you don't have time to get to the Presidio or the Lyon Street stairs. The Pop-Up Fitness Hub at PROXY is our solution to this problem. We'll be the first to admit we've got a little crush on this city. Whether catching the sun rise at Land's End, running sand dunes at Ocean Beach, doing pull-ups along the Embarcadero, or backwards bear crawls all the way up to Coit Tower, we've been going on dates with San Francisco every day for five years. Rain or shine, with our without the company of Karl tour inspiration, our dream girl, if you will. In this video, photographer Eva Kolenko follows founder Jenn Pattee as she travels through San Francisco in a classic Basic Training way, on an epic run to work. It's our tribute to the places and people who make our job so rewarding, a testament to why we love what we do, our love letter to San Francisco. (Special thanks to Geographer for providing their song "Kites.")


What it will look like.

The Basic Training Pop-Up Fitness Hub will include a workout wall, jumping station, and open space. Together, these elements offer the ingredients for a vast array of classes and infinite combinations of movements for circuit training. It’s the ultimate adult playground for adventure race training, working out solo on your way to or from work, or just having a good time with your friends on the weekends.


Outdoor fitness hub

Monkey bars for climbing, open space for gathering, moving, and playing with friends



We need this.

By creating a prototype for a mobile playground that could be replicated and installed throughout San Francisco and beyond, the workout hub's forward-looking design re-imagines what is possible for a parking lot, our health, and the future of urban planning. 


"I am proud to support the efforts of Basic Training on their plans to install an outdoor workout space for public use in Hayes Valley. This communal facility provides a blueprint for a healthy, livable, and vibrant community."  

- Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom 


Spearheaded by California Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom during his tenure as mayor of San Francisco, PROXY has become a revolutionary experiment in urban renewal and interim use. 

Before the Central Freeway was demolished as a result of the Loma Prieta Earthquake, Hayes Valley was lacking any kind of town square or green space. The removal of the freeway provided a unique opportunity to think creatively about the neighborhood. We are now witnessing a vital and vibrant Hayes Valley, and a central piece of this success story is PROXY, currently being developed by Envelope A+D, which won the competitive bid to bring inventive, cutting-edge architectural designs to a set of unused lots at the corner of Hayes and Octavia.

The workout hub will offer exercise opportunities to a greater population than has had access to it before, addressing public health in an innovative way, and playing a role in PROXY’s larger goal of bringing "culture, commerce, and play" to Hayes Valley."

People are using cities in ways urban planners never imagined -- and that's a good thing. We want to make it even easier, and safer, for people to take their workouts outside gyms and into public spaces beautifully designed and specifically built for this purpose,” says Basic Training founder Jennifer Pattee. “Our goal is to make the corner of Hayes and Octavia a bright spot in the neighborhood, and in the bigger story of public health in America today."


Where your money is going.

If we reach our stretch goals, we'll add a filtered water station and outdoor movie screen for community events, guest speakers, and movie nights. 


Custom PUBLIC V7 bike from  Public.



Tshirts and hoodies galore


Discounts on personal training, classes, and packages


The Team

Sandra Possing, Alex Ho, Chris Esquivel, and Jenn Pattee -- the Basic Training team -- have joined forces with Envelope A+D , the architects behind PROXY .  Thanks to the help of furniture designer Julian Paul , graphic designer Bob Dinetz , and an advisory board of experts and strategists, including Dan Pardi , Laura Putnam , Natalie Linden , and Ian Votteri  , we think once you visit our Pop-Up Fitness Hub for the first time, you'll be bear crawling back to PROXY for more.


Let's hook up.

For press inquiries, contact Becca Grites at potluckbekka@gmail.com. For questions about classes, contact info@basictrainingsf.com. For all other questions, contact jenn@basictrainingsf.com 


Facebook
Instagram
Twitter
Yelp
